Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus. Barnett et al. (2012) proposed the black cuxiú for the common name.
The species is cited as Xerosecta sp. in the Italian check-list.

Personal observations by Falkner and Beckmann suggest that the populations are isolated and often exhibit marked morphological differences. These might indicate that the species is polytypic, or even contains cryptic species.
Closely related to A. styrgis, Perry County, Missouri.
Sarcophilus laniarius has also been used recently in light of comparisons between a fossil specimen, S. laniarius (named prior to the naming of S. harrisii), and the extant species (Werdelin 1987).

Gambelia sila was previously placed in the genus Crotaphytus. Except in recent literature, the spelling of the specific name usually has been given as "silus". See Jennings (1995) for an explanation of the spelling change. An isolated population of putative hybrid (G. sila x G. wislizenii) origin has been reported in the Cuyama River drainage system southwest of the southern end of the San Joaquin Valley; apparently hybrids are no longer extant, as a result of habitat loss and local extirpation (Jennings 1995).

The lion tamarins, Leontopithecus, are listed as separate species following Della Serra (1951), Rosenberger and Coimbra-Filho (1984), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Natori (1989), and Rylands et al. (1993). They have been listed as subspecies of L. rosalia by Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier (1972, 1973), Hershkovitz (1977), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Forman et al. (1986) and Seuánez et al. (1988), the latter two publications on the basis of identical chromosome morphologies.

First collected from sites in SE Tanzania (near Newala, Makonde Plateau, in 1953, and Rondo Plateau in 1955) and provisionally identified by R.W. Hayman (in litt.) as Demidoff’s galago Galago demidovii and later Galago demidovii orinus (Jenkins 1987, Honess 1996) due to its small size and morphology. First recognised and described as a species, based on differences in vocalisations and morphology by Honess and Bearder (1996) and subsequently accepted by Groves (2001) and Grubb et al. (2003).

A phylogenetic analysis of the lorisiform primates by Pozzi et al. (2015) showed that Galagoides demidoff and G. thomasi comprise a clade entirely separate from the remaining species currently placed in the genus Galagoides: G. rondoensis, G. orinus, G. zanzibaricus, G. cocos and G. granti. This latter group is sister to Galago É. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire 1796, with the two lineages diverging about 15 mya, and has been attributed to a separate genus Paragalago Masters et al. 2017. Galagoides is now restricted to the western forms: demidoff (G. Fischer, 1806), thomasi (Elliot, 1907), and kumbirensis Svensson, Bersacola, Mills, Munds, Nijman, Perkin, Masters, Couette, Nekaris and Bearder, 2017.
This species is here considered monotypic (Groves 2001). The form ebenus is considered as a distinct species.
Elgaria panamintina was formerly included in the genus Gerrhonotus (see Good 1988).
The generic name was changed from Pipistrellus to Arielulus.

Genetic, vocalization and morphological differences between the populations on Cooloola and Fraser Island and those on North Stradbroke Island indicate that the the latter might represent a distinct species or subspecies (James 2000; E. Meyer unpubl.).
Litoria daviesae, a newly described species, was recently separated from L. subglandulosa by Mahony et al. (2001).
The northern and southern populations could comprise different species (Penman et al. 2004).

authority: Roberts, Horwitz, Wardell-Johnson, Maxson and Mahony, 1997

taxonomicNotes: Analysis supports P. degraaffi, P. mutoni and P. minor as distinct species within the P. Jacksoni complex (Mizerovská et al. 2019). They appear well characterized by ecology and morphology and there is little doubt that they are distinct biological entities (Kennis et al. 2011).

Traditionally, Ateles taxonomy is based on Kellogg and Goldman (1944) that recognize four species: Ateles paniscus (2 subspecies, including Ateles paniscus chamek), A. belzebuth (3 subspecies), A. geoffroyi (9 subspecies) and A. fusciceps (2 subspecies). Froehlich et al. (1991), Medeiros (1994) and Medeiros et al. (1997) argue that A. paniscus is a distinct species without subspecies. Boer and Bruijn (1990) indicated that A. chamek should be considered a full species, while Froehlich et al. (1991) and Collins (2008) classify the taxon as a subspecies of Ateles belzebuth (A. b. chamek). According to Collins (2008), genetic evidence shows that the morphological similarities that spider monkeys of Cocha Cashu National Park in Peru share with A. paniscus in Suriname and the Guiana Shield (black coat and pink face) are superficial and thus should be classified as Ateles belzebuth chamek. Rylands et al. (2000), Rylands and Mittermeier (2009) and Konstant and Rylands (2013) recognize A. chamek as a distinct species. According to van Roosmalen and van Roosmalen (2014) the species of spider monkey that occurs throughout the interfluve between the Rios Madeira, Mamoré, Guaporé and Tapajós, an area recognized for the occurrence of A. chamek, should be Ateles longimembris. In this region, Cruz Lima (1945) recognized this spider monkey as a subspecies of Ateles paniscus, while Groves (2001) considered A. longimembris as a synonym of A. chamek. Van Roosmalen and van Roosmalen (2014) report what they regard it as a distinct species of Ateles occurring between the Rios Purus and Madeira, south and west of the Rio Ipixuna (right bank tributary of the Rio Purus).

This species was previously known as Callicebus modestus (Lönnberg, 1939). Taxonomical assessments of titi monkeys recognized different numbers of species groups (Hershkovitz 1963, 1988, 1990, Kobayashi 1995, Kobayashi and Langguth 1999, van Roosmalen et al. 2002, Groves 2005). A completely new phylogenetic arrangement of these primates (Byrne et al. 2016), divides Callicebus into three genera: Cheracebus, Callicebus, and Plecturocebus. According to this last assessment, Plecturocebus modestus is found in the donacophilus group, along with P. donacophilus, P. oenanthe, P. olallae, P. pallescens and P. urubambensis.The morphological similarity between P. modestus and P. olallae demanded further investigation (Tarifa 1996, Anderson 1997, Felton et al. 2006). Recent field observations (Martinez and Wallace 2007), as well as opportunistically collected specimens (Martinez et al. 2013), and results from a scat-based genetic study (Wallace et al. 2013, Barreta et al. in press) support the taxonomic separation of P. modestus and P. olallae.

Nomascus nasutus has been variously considered either as a species in its own right (sometimes as conspecific with N. hainanus), or as a subspecies of N. concolor; it is here recognized as a species distinct from N. hainanus and N. concolor, based on differences in vocalizations and fur colouration as well as genetic evidence (Mootnick and Fan 2011; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010, 2011; Feng et al. 2014).

Previously, Nomascus hainanus was variously considered either a species in its own right or as a subspecies of N. concolor or N. nasutus; it is here recognized as a distinct species based on molecular, vocalization and pelage differences (Geissmann et al. 2000; Mootnick 2006; Roos and Nadler 2005; Roos et al. 2007; Thinh et al. 2010, 2011).

Previously considered to occur in Australian waters, but the Australian individuals were recently described as a new species, Hemigaleus australiensis (White et al. 2005). Specimens from the Red Sea need to be critically examined.
Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2005) both recognise two subspecies: C. e. camerunensis (from between the Cross/Benue and Sanaga Rivers), and C. e. erythrotis (endemic to Bioko).
Groves (2001) and Grubb et al. (2003) recognize two subspecies: C. e. erythrogaster and C. e. pococki. It belongs to the Cercopithecus cephus species group.
Considered under the genus Lymnaea by Hubendick (1952), but most other researchers support placement under Erinna.

Hershkovitz (1977), Eisenberg (1989), Rylands et al. (1993) and Rylands and Mittermeier (2008) listed the black-handed tamarin as a subspecies of Saguinus midas. It is now considered as a distinct species (Rylands et al. 1993, 2000; Groves 2001, 2005). Vallinoto et al. (2006) indicated that the Rio Tocantins could act as a barrier to gene flow for Saguinus niger. This was presaged in a molecular genetic analysis by Tagliaro et al. (2005). The form described as Mystax ursulus umbratus Thomas, 1922, from Cametá, Rio Tocantins, Pará, listed by Groves (2001, 2005) as a junior synonym of S. niger, and by Hershkovitz (1977) as a junior synonym of S. midas niger, was indicated as a distinct geographical race or species (J. de Sousa e Silva Jr. pers. comm., cited in Rylands and Mittermeier 2008). Recently, Gregorinand and de Vivo (2013) revalidated Saguinus ursula Hoffmannsegg, 1807 as a distinct species from Saguinus niger. Based on pelage coloration, pattern of morphological divergence and molecular data, the authors described the samples from the east bank of the Tocantins River as S. ursulus which are distinct from specimens of S. niger from the west bank. Saguinus niger and S. ursulus are allopatric, and the Tocantins River is acting as an effective barrier for gene flow (Gregorin and De Vivo 2013).

The taxonomy of Glyphis species is problematic, partly because of the lack of museum specimens. Glyphis garricki can be confused with the Bull Shark (Carcharhinus leucas) by non-specialists as the latter is known to occur in the same habitat and possibly occupies the known range of the former at some stages of its life cycle. Glyphis garricki can be distinguished from the Bull Shark by its taller second dorsal fin (about two-thirds the height of the first dorsal), the triangular shape of the first dorsal fin, and the small eye located on the grey-shaded part of the head as opposed to the white counter-shaded part. Additionally, when Glyphis garricki is alive it is steely grey in colour in comparison to the yellowish grey of the Bull Shark (Larson 2000 cited in Pogonoski et al. 2002). Glyphis garricki is also very difficult to distinguish from other Glyphis species and accurate identifications need to include x-rays of the vertebral column (see Taniuchi et al. 1991). It is possibly the same species that occurs in the Fly River of Papua New Guinea (Compagno 2002). Future research on Glyphis species is urgently required to solve the inherent taxonomic problems in the group.

A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".

The earlier Cape records (Pinhey 1984) are doubtful and are probably Pseudagrion hageni hageni (Samways 2006).

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus. 

The species name is currently in dispute. Hershkovitz (1985) named the subspecies Chiropotes satanas utahicki. However, as the species is named after a woman, in subsequent revisions authors renamed the species Chiropotes (satanas) utahickae (Silva Jr. and Figueiredo 2002; Groves 2005). Brandon-Jones et al. (2006) argue that the Latin gender suffix is part of its etymology and therefore unregulated by Article 31 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, and that the author's selected suffix should be respected and the original spelling preserved.

Hill (1962) listed five subspecies of the red-handed howler monkey, Alouatta belzebul: A. b. belzebul (Linnaeus, 1766) (restricted by Cabrera [1957] to the Rio Capim, eastern Pará); A. b. discolor (Spix, 1823) from Gurupá, Pará; A. b. ululata Elliot, 1912, from Miritiba, Maranhão; A. b. mexianae Hagmann, 1908, from the island of Mexiana, in the Marajó Archipelago, Brazil; and A. b. nigerrima Lönnberg, 1941 (restricted by Cabrera [1957] to Patinga, Amazonas).

Groves (2001, 2005) considered A. discolor (Spix, 1823) and A. ululata Elliot, 1912, to be synonyms of A. belzebul. Here we follow Gregorin (2006) who recognised the forms discolor and ululata as full species based in morphology of the cranium and hyoid apparatus and pelage colour and patterns.
Synonyms = Ctenosaura quinquecarinata (in part) sensu Bailey, 1928 and other authors before 2001; Enyaliosaurus quinquecarinatus (in part).

Chalinolobus neocaledonicus has been considered a synonym of C. gouldii by some authors (e.g., Tidemann 1986, Chruszcz and Barclay 2002), but we follow Simmons (2005) in provisionally treating it as a distinct species.
There are two proposed subspecies/evolutionary significant units (ESUs) recognized by the New Zealand Bat Recovery Group and the New Zealand Department of Conservation (Winnington 1999).
This species is now considered a synonym of Thalassophryne maculosa (Collette and Greenfield 2009).
Voucher specimens held at the American Museum of Natural History and University of Michigan Museum of Zoology.

The placement of Pantanodon is problematic. Based on the most recent studies, it should be placed under Poeciliidae (Parenti 1981, Ghedotti 2000) (J. Sparks pers. comm.).

Voucher specimens held at the American Museum of Natural History and University of Michigan Museum of Zoology.

Voucher specimens held at the American Museum of Natural History and University of Michigan Museum of Zoology. Submitted as Paratilapia sp. nov. 'Vondrozo' and subsequently changed to Paratilapia sp. nov. 'Vevembe' on recommendation of Paul Loiselle.
This is an undescribed species with voucher specimens held at the American Museum of Natural History and University of Michigan Museum of Zoology.
Voucher specimens held at the American Museum of Natural History and University of Michigan Museum of Zoology.
Voucher specimens held at the American Museum of Natural History and University of Michigan Museum of Zoology
Voucher specimens held at the American Museum of Natural History and University of Michigan Museum of Zoology.

Bigelow and Schroeder (1953) provide good descriptions of the two species R. bonasus and R. brasiliensis from Brazilian material but admitted at the same time that the two forms may not be separate species. The name R. brasiliensis was not used again until a few years ago. Figueiredo (1977) cites only R. bonasus for Southwest Brazil and this may be the reason why subsequent authors assigned catches of Rhinoptera from this area to R. bonasus.

However Gallo-da-Silva et al. (1997 in Menni and Stehmann 2000) confirmed the existence of both species off Rio de Janeiro, and all three specimens of Rhinoptera collected off Rio Grande do Sul in the 1980s were R. brasiliensis (Soto unpub. data).

The two species differ in the size at birth. According to data listed by Bigelow and Schroeder (1953), R. brasiliensis has a broader mouth and greater distances between nostrils and between spiracles than R. bonasus, and this corresponds with the difference between the two species in the tooth plate conformation, brasiliensis having three central rows of broad teeth and bonasus only one such row.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonutes) infravallatus. Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes infravallatus.
Hybridizes as a brown hybrid with S. priam where parapatric.

Simmons (2005) records that this species has been formerly included in Rhinolophus maclaudi (e.g., Smith and Hood 1980) or R. ruwenzorri (e.g., Csorba et al. 2003), but was found by Fahr et al. (2002) to be distinct from both of these species.
This taxon was initially included within Rhinolophus maclaudi by Koopman (1993), but has more recently been recognized as a valid species (see Fahr et al. 2002, Csorba et al. 2003 and Simmons 2005).
A split from the R. maclaudi complex. Other similar species include R. ruwenzorii and R. hilli.
This species is closely related to F. anselli and F. micklemi with only 1.4% divergence on the cytochrome b gene between these three species (Ingram et al. 2004; Van Daele et al. 2007).
This species was previously a synonym of Otomys anchietae. It was found to be distinct by Taylor and Kumurai (2001).
This species was previously considered a subspecies of Otomys tropicalis.

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus.
Was listed in the 1996 Red List as prespensis which was incorrectly spelt.

Clupeonella muhlisi from Lake Apolyond (in Sea of Marmara basin in Turkey) usually considered as a synonym of C. abrau is a synonym of C. cultriventris. Both species cannot be distinguished by morphological or molecular characters. Also Clupeonella abrau is very closely related to C. cultriventris and is not supported as an own evolutionary lineage by molecular data (COI). However, the morphological differences suggest that it is a young species evolved from C. cultriventris. Therefore, we keep C. abrau as a valid species in the Red List.
Coelops hirsutus was previously considered a subspecies of Coelops robinsoni (Corbet and Hill 1992), however, we follow L. Heaney (pers. comm. 2007) in considering it to be a distinct species.

Grubb et al. (2003) list two subspecies: C. s. satanas from Bioko, and C. s. anthracinus from the mainland.

Groves (2001, 2007) listed Colobus satanas anthracinus from Gabon (see Gautier-Hion et al. 1999) as a junior synonym of Colobus satanas (which occurs on Bioko Island). Groves (2005) and Grubb et al. (2003), however, listed it as a valid subspecies. Oates et al. (2000) found that the loud calls (roar pulse rate) of the two forms were significantly distinct (lower in C. s. satanas).

We retain all the above listed populations (including some winter spawning ones) in C. trybomi. Allozyme data suggest that the different populations have arisen independently from a sympatric population of autumn spawning ciscoes and are distinct species. In this case, three of the four species endemic to Sweden are already extinct.
There are taxonomic difficulties with this species, and it is possible that Ansonia rubigina is a synonym of it (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species might be a synonym of Ansonia ornata (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
There is an ongoing debate on the genus placement of this species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
This species was elevated to species status by La Marca (1983).

The nomenclatural history of this species was detailed by Lötters et al. (1998) and Lötters and La Marca (2001). This species was redescribed by Lötters, La Marca and Vences (2004) after the discovery that the original type material represented Atelopus varius of Central America. The former junior synonym Atelopus vogli is considered to be a distinct species following (Lötters et al. 2004)
Inclusion in genus Rhaebo is provisional (Frost 2014).

Cocroft et al. (1990) and Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that Atelopus spumarius might be a complex of more than one species. Lescure and Marty (2001) recognize two subspecies: A. s. barbotini Lescure 1981; and A. s. hoogmoedi Lescure 1973 without arguments and in contrast to their earlier opinion. Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that A. spumarius occurs in the upper Amazon Basin only (Peru, Colombia, Brazil); populations from southern Peru, Ecuador and central Brazil might refer to undescribed taxa within A. spumarius sensu lato. Populations from the Guianas and eastern Amazonia might be treated as A. hoogmoedi complex (maybe within A. spumarius sensu lato). Atelopus spumarius hoogmoedi is a synonym of A. spumarius under Lescure and Gasc (1986). This form is understood by Lescure and Gasc (1986) to be more or less A. spumarius sensu lato; however, A. spumarius hoogmoedi is not conspecific with A. spumarius sensu stricto (S. Lötters pers. comm.)
Lötters et al. (2011) elevated A. spumarius barbotini to species level.

Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). The species has a variable appearance and color and pattern are poor diagnostic characteristics for identification of this species (Richards and Knowles 2007). Some subpopulations have a very yellow color, resembling Atelopus zeteki, which is why both Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki are sometimes referred to as golden frogs in Panama (Estrada et al. 2014). Genetic analysis of mitochondrial DNA reveals support for recognizing A. varius and A. zeteki as separate clades, but sorting of haplotypes was imperfect and Costa Rican samples sorted into a third outlying group (Richards and Knowles 2007). Genetic examination of the phylogeny of this group would be helpful, but the extreme declines of this group will make sourcing of fresh, genomic quality tissues challenging.
The taxonomy and relationships of this species need re-evaluation (Biju 2001).

Four subspecies have been described: P. l. longinasus in Pinar del Río; P. l. cajalbanensis in the Cajálbana Plateau, also in Pinar del Río; P. l. dunni in the mountains of Guamuhaya; and P. l. ramsdeni in the Sierra del Guaso. (González Alonso et al., 2012)
This species was elevated from subspecific status under Peltophryne guentheri by Powell (1993).
This species is currently under taxonomic review.

Harvey and Smith (1993) pointed out that Rhinella echinodes, described by Reynolds and Foster (1992), is a synonym of R. quechua. There is an unconfirmed record in Cotapata National Park in La Paz (Cortez 2001). This species is possibly a complex of more than one species.
Due to its morphological intermediacy between Duttaphrynus and Amietophrynus, Frost has returned this concept to the uncertain status of "Bufo" scorteccii.

The Colombian populations have different skin texture and some morphological differences compared to Ecuadorian populations. More research is needed to determine whether or not this is in fact two separate species (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).
Elevated to full species status by Klappenbach and Langone (1992).

Señaris et al. (1994) described this monotypic genus based on osteological and morphological characters of adults. Until now, this taxon has not been included in phylogenetic studies. Barrio-Amorós (1998) emended the name sosai to sosae, without explanation. However, recently Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) justified this change.
The identity of the specimens from the northern part of Parque Nacional Llanganates requires confirmation.

This species is a complex of species, hence its apparently varying conservation status in the different countries in its range (J.V. Rueda pers. comm., G. Gonzalez pers. comm. July 2018 Guayasamin et al. 2008).
This species may be a synonym of Centrolene lynchi (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016).

This species had not been evaluated in any phylogenetic analysis. Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this taxon as incertae sedis within the genus Cochranella sensu lato until more data becomes available.

Duellman (1981) originally placed the taxon in the genus Centrolenella, which was subsequently designated to Cochranella by Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) based on the absence of humeral spines in males from specimens collected at Campamento Chancos, Valle del Cauca. However, Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006) verified the presence of humeral spines in the material described by Duellman (1981), thus combining the taxon with Centrolene; the Colombian material reported by Lynch and Ruiz-Carranza (1996) were therefore presumed to be of a distinct lineage (Cisneror-Heredia and McDiarmid 2006). The lack of clarity regarding Colombian specimens is reflected in many published accounts (e.g. Acosta-Galvis 2000, Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2007, Guayasamin and Frenkel 2018).

Later, in a monographic revision of the glassfrog family, Centrolenidae, Guayasamin et al. (2009) underscored the difficulty of substantively designating the taxon at the generic level, and regarded the taxon as incertae sedis within the subfamily Centroleninae. Finally, after incorporating mitochondrial sequences into a phylogenetic analysis of the family, Guayasamin et al. (2019) determined its placement within Nymphargus based on recent material from the Río Manduriacu Reserve, Imbabura, Ecuador (Maynard et al. in press). New material for N. balionotus from Colombia has not been reported in recent decades. Thus, it is not currently possible to resolve whether or not the subpopulation from Campamento Chancos is representative of a distinct lineage from those in Ecuador, as suggested by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006). However, it is plausible that this scenario is correct based on available information; in addition to lacking humeral spines, the records from Campamento Chancos are well separated from, and substantially lower in elevation than all other specimens (Maynard et al. in press).
Recently transferred from Hyalinobatrachium to Cochranella by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007).
In the past, some specimens of this species were considered to be Hyalinobatrachium fleishmanni.

It is possible that two species might be included in Hyalinobatrachium orientale in Venezuela, one being the species from the type locality, and the other an undescribed form from Macizo del Turimiquire. Animals on Tobago might also belong to a different species.
It has been suggested that this species is not native to Martinique, but is synonymous with another species from South America (M. Breuil pers. comm.).

Originally assigned to Prostherapis by Rivero (1961) and later transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971). Grant et al. (2006) did not include this species in their phylogenetic hypothesis, however agree with La Marca (2004) in that its phylogenetic relationships remain enigmatic, and refer it as insertae sedis within Aromobatidae.
Molecular data suggest that Allobates kingsburyi is a species complex (L.A. Coloma pers. comm.).
Based on morphological analyses, Verdade and Rodrigues (2007) allocate all Atlantic Forest species of Allobates to synonymy with Allobates olfersioides.
Since its description (La Marca 1994) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Santos et al. 2014, Grant et al. 2017).
This frog was tentativelly assigned to Mannophryne herminae, but its taxonomic status needs further research (La Marca 1999).

Morphological and chromosomal evidence support the hypothesis that Mannophryne trinitatis is restricted to the island of Trinidad (Barrio-Amorós et al., 2006). The population from Península de Paria, Venezuela, has been found to be a different species, Mannophryne venezuelensis (Manzanilla et al., 2007).

Previous to Grant et al. (2006) the genus Aromobates was known only by a single species: A. nocturnus (Myers et al. 1991). Then, Grant et al. (2006) moved all Colostethus of the alboguttatus group (sensu Rivero 1988) or Nephelobates (sensu La Marca 1994) to Aromobates and provided a well-corroborated phylogeny of the genus. Barrio-Amorós & Santos (2012) provide a phylogeny and a list with current threats for all species of the genus. Rivero (1982a) included Colostehus inflexus Rivero, 1978 in the synonymy of C. alboguttatus. Myers, Paolillo and Daly (1991) and La Marca (1997) revive the species as Nephelobates inflexus in their works without explanation. Recently, Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) consider inflexus different from A. alboguttatus and a valid species, but waiting proper attention.

There are two subspecies: Argenteohyla siemersi siemersi and A. s. pederseni. Taxonomic studies are ongoing to evaluate the taxonomic status of the two subspecies; preliminary results do not support the hypothesis that A. s. pederseni and A. s. siemersi represent distinct species, but rather the same species with color variants (R. Cajade pers. comm. September 2017).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich, et al. 2005). The taxonomic relationship between G. cornuta and G. ceratophrys needs to be clarified (Luis A. Coloma pers. comm. 2007). It is possible that the specimen collected from Manta Real, Ecuador, represents a new species (Ana Almendáriz pers. comm. 2007). Overall, while there appear to be variations between the Central American and South American individuals, Duellmann and Trueb (2015) noted that they are insufficiently distinguished based on physical characteristics alone and that no clear pattern exists between the variations.
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

The original type locality of this species was Panama, but this is in error according to Savage and Heyer (1969) who suggested that the type specimen might have come from Colombia, Peru or Bolivia. Subsequently, Duellman and De la Riva (1999) found a single specimen. Based on morphological characters, it is suspected that this species may be the senior synonym of at least two other common species of the region (I. De la Riva pers. comm. Sept 2019). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). This taxon may be a junior synonym of S. arborescandens (Caviedes-Solis 2013 - THESIS).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Ptychohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.

Toal and Mendelson (1995) considered S. celata to occur in the Sierra de Juárez and also tentatively near Totontepec in the Sierra Mixe, but specimens from the Sierra Mixe were reassigned to S. cyclada (Campbell and Duellman 2000).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then Duellman et al. (2016) placed it within the genus Sarcohyla.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was rediscovered by J. Aparicio and S. Reichle in 1997 at the type locality.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005).

De la Riva et al. (2000) registered a slight doubt as to the taxonomic validity of the species. Faivovich and De la Riva (2006), however, continue to recognize it as a valid species, pending a revision of subpopulations associated with the name Hyloscirtus armatus. In the Hyloscirtus armatus group according to Faivovich and De la Riva (2006).

Dendrosophus pelidna has been synonymized under this species by Guarnizo et al. (2012).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The form occurring in El Salvador and Honduras is considered a separate species, Plectrohyla psiloderma (McCranie and Wilson 1999a).

This species is possibly a species complex, and further taxonomic work needs to be carried out to verify the identity of Honduran and Guatamalan subpopulations (Duellman and Campbell 1992, J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
Juvenile specimens collected from the eastern part of the Sierra de las Minas (MVZ collection) are not thought to belong to this species (J. Campbell pers. comm. August 2019).
There is considerable doubt regarding the validity of this species.
The forms that occur in Honduras have been separated to form the species Plectrohyla exquisita (McCranie and Wilson 1998).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis by Faivovich et al. (2005). Subsequently, it was moved from Hylomantis to Agalychnis by Favivovich et al. (2010).
This species was removed from synonymy of Ptychohyla euthysanota by Campbell and Smith (1992).
Genus change from Ptychohyla to Atlantihyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
Genus change from Ptychohyla to Quilticohyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
The use of this name has been clarified by McCranie and Wilson (1993). This species has been moved from Ptychohyla to Atlantihyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
This species was removed from synonymy (as a subspecies) of Scinax catharinae by Peixoto (1988).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Populations from mainland Africa assigned to this species are now considered to be Leptopelis rufus.
This species has previously been assigned to the genus Nesionixalus.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was formerly considered a synonym of Pristimantis fenestratus by Lynch (1980), but it was elevated to species status by Kohler (2000a).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

The taxonomic allocation of the western subpopulation to this species was questioned by S.B. Hedges and L. Diaz. The western subpopulation of this species was removed from this concept for its reassessment in 2013 (J. Luedtke pers. comm. July 2015).
The genus Paramophrynella was proposed by La Marca (2007); Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Paramophrynella in the synonymy of Pristimantis, which includes Pristimantis boconoensis.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

La Marca (2007) recently erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis.

Eleutherodactylus dixoni Lynch 1991 is a synonym of E. albolabris (Taylor 1943).

Taylor (1943) first described Tomodactylus albolabris, which Hedges (1989) later reclassified as a species of Eleutherodactylus (Syrrhophus). Prompted by this merger, Lynch (1991) proposed E. dixoni as a replacement name forE. albolabris, believing it to be a junior secondary homonym of Microbatrachylus albolabris Taylor 1939 because that genus had also been combined with Eleutherodactylus (Lynch 1965). However, M. albolabris had already been synonymized with M. pygmaeus by Duellman (1961), obviating the need for a replacement name. Thus, the earliest name available for this taxon is Eleutherodactylus (Syrrhophus) albolabris.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
The genus Paramophrynella was proposed by La Marca (2007), which included P. ginesi; Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Paramophrynella in the synonymy of Pristimantis.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This species is probably a junior synonym of Craugastor xucanebi (J. Campbell and C. Grunwald pers. comm. 2019).

La Marca (2007) recently erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis.

Recent taxonomic analyses have revealed that P. ornatissimus may include more than one species (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm.).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Genetic analysis of animals in the captive collection may represent disparate cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This is a complex of probably at least five species (J. Campbell pers. comm. August 2019).

La Marca (2007) recently erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was separated from Eleutherodactylus bransfordii by Savage (2002).
Some historic records of Eleutherodactylus pinarensis might refer to juveniles of E. klinikowskii, and so are not included here (L. Díaz pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Eleutherodactylus rugulosus (Campbell and Savage 2000).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This species is probably a junior synonym of Craugastor xucanebi (J. Campbell and C. Grunwald pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). We follow Lynch (2000b) in separating Eleutherodactylus loki from E. rhodopis.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species is probably a complex of several species.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

There is uncertainty about the taxonomic status of this name in Venezuela. Kaiser, Hardy and Green (1994) state that South American records are based on misidentifications. J. Hardy (pers. comm.) has seen specimens from Venezuela in North American institutions; these are in poor condition and are mis-identifications of Pristimantis urichi. Here we consider the species to be endemic to Trinidad and Tobago, not occurring on the South American mainland.
We follow De la Riva et al. (2000) in considering this species to be separate from Telmatobius marmoratus, and also follow De la Riva (2004) in considering T. jahuira as a synonym of T. verrucosus.
Telmatobius albiventris and Telmatobius crawfordi were synonymized with this species by Benavides, Ortiz and Sites (2002).
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Oreolalax major but did not give any reason.
Inger et al. (1990) considered Oreolalax puxiongensis to be synonymous with O. schmidti.
Zhao and Adler (1993) regarded this species to be synonymous with Scutiger ruginosus (= S. mammatus) without discussion.

Diagnosis: This species is closely related to Scutiger chintingensis (Liu et Hu), but differs from the latter by 1) upper jaw toothless, and 2) very rough skin with black spines as much as scuttered over the whole body.

Fei, Ye and Chen (1986) considered that this taxa is just a polymorphic form of Scutiger gladulatus and Scutiger mammatus. It has been reported from two locations but one of these might refer to S. muliensis.
This species was synonymized with Leptobrachium ailaonicum by Cuc et al. (1999), although this was rejected by Ohler et al. (2000).
Fei et al. (1999) considered this taxon to be a subspecies of Xenophrys minor but did not provide any explanation. We here consider it to be a full species.
This species has been reported from several additional localities, although these likely refer to undescribed species (S.D. Biju pers. comm.)
Amolops daiyunensis was considered a synonym of A. hongkongensis by Yang (1991), but we follow Fei et al. (1999), Jin et al. (2005) and Ngo et al. (2006) in treating it as a separate species.
The supopulation in Atewa, Ghana is most likely a separate species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
A number of specimens referred to this species in the past are likely to have been misidentified (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

Rao (1937) originally described this taxon as Philautus kottigeharensis based on a single specimen from Kottigehar. Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred the species from Philautus to Micrixalus. The holotype was lost and recently Bossuyt and Milinkovitch (2001) relocated the species from Bhadrea in Chicamangalore District very near to the type locality. Formal designation of the neotype is under way (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
A number of specimens assigned to Micrixalus nudis are thought to be misidentifications. A detailed taxonomic study is required for further clarification (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999). The taxonomy of this species is unclear at present; it might be a synonym of a Southeast Asian species.
This species is part of the Limnonectes modestus complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
There is quite considerable intraspecific variation in this taxon (Biju 2001).

Fei et al. (2000) in transferred this species from Rana to Pseudoamolops, but we retain it in Rana. High-altitude populations are now regarded as a separate species, Rana multidenticulata (Chou and Lin 1997a).
This species is endemic to China and records of this species from Tibet are in fact Nanorana chayuensis (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).
This form probably represents two separate species.

This species is now regarded as being endemic to the island of Karpathos; populations on Rhodes that were previously assigned to this species are now allocated to P. bedriagae (Lymberakis et al. 2007). The taxonomy of Pelophylax is complex and further studies are ongoing.
The species status of Pelophylax cretensis is "confirmed" by short mtDNA sequences and a large number of private allozyme alleles not found in any other water frog (P. Beerli pers. comm.).
This species is a member of the Lithobates pipiens complex.
This species does not produce hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).

authority: (Cuellar, Méndez-De La Cruz and Villagrán-Santa Cruz, 1996)

taxonomicNotes: Northern subpopulations might represent a distinct species. Smith and Ciszar (2003) consider the record of L. pustulosus from 13 km W Matáchic, Chihuahua, Mexico, to actually refer to L. chiricahuensis.
We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana hmongorum, described by Bain et al. (2003), as a synonym of this species.

authority: Huang, Fei & Ye in Fei and Ye, 2001

taxonomicNotes: This species requires taxonomic revision (M. Acevedo pers. comm. August 2019).
Genetic studies showed that this form is distinct from populations of Lithobates capito and L. areolata, and has therefore been established as a separate species (Young and Crother 1991).

Although Schneider and Haxhiu (1994) had difficulty distinguishing the voice of Pelophylaxa shqipericus from that of P. lessonae, morphology, allozymes, mtDNA sequences, and crossing experiments all indicate that P. shqipericus is very distinct from P. lessonae. Its relationships with other western Palearctic water frogs are less clear (T. Uzzell pers. comm.). This species does not make hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).

This species was synonymized with Pelophylax nigromaculatus by Fei, Ye and Huang (1991), and this synonymy was accepted by Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (1996). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) still consider this to be a valid species and hence it is included here pending a definitive decision on its taxonomic status.
NEED TO CONTACT J. JIANPING FOR LATEST TAXONOMIC REVISION, THIS SPECIES MAY NOT BE P. MONGOLICA

authority: (Xu in Wu, Xu, Dong, Li & Liu, 1983)

taxonomicNotes: Populations from southeastern Xizang, China have been identified as Nasutixalus medogensis, and were previously confused with T. moloch (Jiang et al. 2016).
This species is known only from the holotype which has been misplaced. The type description is not detailed enough to determine whether this species is still extant.
P. hoffmanni will be placed into synonymy with this species (Madhava in prep).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Philautus microtympanum by Dutta and Manamendra-Arachchi (1996).
Philautus sanctipalustris is an incorrect subsequent spelling of Philautus sanctisilvaticus according to Bossuyt and Dubois (2001).
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus nanus (Günther, 1858) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
We follow Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) in considering this species to be separate from Philautus microtympanum, and belonging to the genus Philautus, rather than Polypedates.
Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) suggested that this species could be a synonym of Ixalus beddomii Günther, 1876. However, recent studies indicate that both species are distinct (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

Specimens of Philautus charius recorded from Ponmudi Hills and surroundings and Wayanad were assessed separately as new undescribed species Philautus sp. nov. "Kalpatta" (S.D. Biju pers. comm.). This species was subsequently described as P. anili Biju and Bossuyt, 2006.
Specimens refered to this species from Ponmudi and surroundings in India, are now included in the newly described species, Philautus sp. nov. 'Ponmudi Hills' (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species assessment is based on the recent taxonomic revision by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus nanus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005). Further taxonomic studies on this species are required.
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
This species was moved to the genus Philautus from Theloderma by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
Specimens recorded from Ponmudi Hills (and possibly Wayanad) as Philautus signatus are in the process of being described as the new species Philautus sp. nov. 'Ponmudi_3' (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species was previously assessed as Philautus sp. nov. 'Amboli Forest'.
This species was first reported by Inger et al. (1984) from Ponmudi as Philautus femoralis.
This species was previously placed in the genera Rhacophorus and Polypedates.

Ye, Fei and Hu (1993) stated that the distinguishing features between Batrachuperus tibetanus and B. karlschmidti (colouration and the number of gill filaments) are quite variable and that the two taxa should be synonymized. Fu et al. (2001) confirmed the distinctiveness of B. karlschmidti, and suggested, on the basis of molecular evidence, that the nominal B. tibetanus comprises four species, three of which are undescribed. Fu and Zeng (2008) suggested that molecular data did not support the recognition of Batrachuperus taibaiensis apart from Batrachuperus tibetanus, but refrained from a taxonomic change at the time pending further evaluation of morphology. These species were placed into synonymy by Fei and Ye (2016).

Nishikawa et al. (2001) demonstrate that the populations on Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu belong to three separate species, but the formal naming of the populations on Shikoku and Kyushu is pending. Hynobius boulengeri is here provisionally treated as a single species.

The population currently allocated to Hynobius chinensis from Fujian Province, China, might represent a new species. We retain the Fujian population in H. chinensis until further taxonomic studies are undertaken. We consider H. yiwuensis (Cai 1985) to be a valid species separate from H. chinensis following Fei et al. (1990) and Fu et al. (2003).
This taxon was recently reallocated to the new genus Ghatixalus and is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus asterops (Biju et al. 2008).

There is significant doubt as to the validity of this species as its type locality cannot be located, it has not been positively identified since its description, and no genetic work has been conducted on the holotype (Mexico Red List Assessment Workshop October 2019).

The species boundaries between Ambystoma granulosum, A. lermaense and A. rivularis require further investigation. However, these three taxa are clearly differentiated from all other Mexican ambystomatids (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).

The species was previously included in the genus Rhyacosiredon. Based on unpublished allozyme and mtDNA sequence data, it is a well-defined taxon distinct from Ambystoma (Rhyacosiredon) altimirani (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).
This taxon might be a complex of several species (Highton 2000).

It is not clear that all the Panamanian and the Colombian subpopulations belong to the same species, and the subpopulations from Comarca Guna Yala may belong to an undescribed species but taxonomic work is required and it is retained in this concept until that time (Panama Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). Even within Colombia there might be several species within this concept.
Hynobius yiwuensis is here treated as a valid species, separate from H. chinensis, following Fei et al. (1999) and Fu et al. (2003).
This species might be a complex of more than one species.
This species might be a synonym of Pachyhynobius shangchengensis.
It is possible that this species is a complex, with at least three distinct species in Panama (Hertz 2015 thesis).
This species was originally confused with Bolitoglossa striatula.

authority: Hu and Fei in Hu, Fei and Ye, 1978
taxonomicNotes: Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon, rather than Pseudohynobius. Zhao (1990) and Zhao and Adler (1993) indicated that this species is a synonym of Liua tsinpaensis. However, the karyotypes of these two species are significantly different. Hence, Ye, Fei and Hu (1993) and Fei (1999) still regarded it to be a valid species in Pseudohynobius, and we follow this arrangement here.

authority: (Liu and Hu in Hu, Zhao and Liu, 1966)
taxonomicNotes: Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon, rather than Pseudohynobius. Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus was considered to be a synonym of this species by Zhao and Hu (1983) and Zhao and Wu (1995), but is considered a valid species by Ye et al. (1993) and Fei et al. (1999).

Subpopulations in south-east Costa Rica and north-west Panama have been separated as Bolitoglossa sombra and B. magnifica (Hanken et al. 2005). However, this species and B. sombra appear to be genetically similar and may actually represent the same species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).

This form was formerly considered to be part of Bolitoglossa subpalmata, but has since been removed from synonymy (Savage 2002). Several species might still be involved in what is now considered B. pesrubra.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under revision, and it is likely that the distribution of this species will be restricted in the future (Townsend et al. in review March 2019).
Localities in the Caribbean drainage of northern Costa Rica, as mentioned by Brame and Wake (1963) refer to misidentified specimens of B. alvaradoi (Hertz 2015).
There may be more than one distinct species within this taxon, but this needs to be verified through taxonomic research (Hertz 2015, Panama Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).

Jacobs (1987) found Eurycea junaluska to be genetically similar to E. aquatica and E. cirrigera and questioned the taxonomic status of E. junaluska. Sever (1989) found E. junaluska to be morphologically unique and genetically distinct from all sympatric Eurycea.
This form might represent a species complex.

Gyrinophilus gulolineatus was formerly regarded as a subspecies of G. palleucus; it was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002) and Crother et al. (2000). Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus.

Three subspecies (palleucus, gulolineatus, and necturoides) have been recognized; intergradation between palleucus and necturoides is evident in some Alabama populations (A. Wynne, in Godwin 1995b). Some populations do not conform well to any of the named subspecies. One form in Tennessee might be sufficiently distinct biochemically to warrant recognition as a separate species (Redmond and Scott 1996). Gyrinophilus gulolineatus (Berry Cave Salamander) was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002), and Crother et al. (2000), but Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus. In this assessment, Gyrinophilus gulolineatus is regarded as a distinct species.
As assessed here, this taxon is restricted to northern Costa Rica (Savage 2000). It is possible that the southwest subpopulation may be described as a new species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
The taxonomic issues surrounding this species have now been resolved, which has resulted in the description of two new species, Nototriton nelsoni and N. oreadorum (Townsend 2016).
The eastern subpopulations (e.g., San Ramon) are taxonomical uncertain (B. Kubicki and E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
The type specimen has been lost. In the past the species name has been applied to populations of Chiropterotriton in southern Mexico that are no longer assigned to this species.

Darda (1994) split this species into two, but did not provide a formal name for the southernmost population (in Hidalgo State). In this account we treat all four known populations as Chiropterotriton multidentatus, pending the formal description of the southernmost population.
Removed from the synonymy of Chiropterotriton chiropterus by Darda (1994).

Both Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were included within Dendrotriton rabbi in the past; however, this species is now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010). There may be an undescribed species within this species concept (C. Vásquez Almazán pers. comm. August 2019).

Salamanders from springs in the vicinity of Lake Georgetown display a unique combination of alleles and have distinctive mtDNA characteristics; possibly they may also be distinguished based on pigmentation characteristics (Chippindale, Hillis and Price 1994). It is regarded as a distinct species by Chippindale, Hillis and Price (1994) and was formally described as Eurycea naufragia by Chippindale et
al. (2000). It was included in E. neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982).

This species is included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982) and in previous publications. Certain populations provisionally assigned to this species warrant further study and might prove to be taxonomically distinct (Chippindale et al. 2000).
Mexican subpopulation may correspond to an undescribed species of Pseudoeurycea (S. Rovito pers. comm. 2019).
The animals in Mexico might belong to a new species, however new tissue samples are needed to confirm this (G. Parra-Olea pers. comm. 2007).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to P. nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northern Algeria.

Recent morphological, ecological and genetic studies on Salamandra algira indicate that there are two major clades further subdivided in several lineages (Beukema et al. 2010, Hassine et al. 2016, Dinis et al. 2019), which are recognized as distinct subspecies: S.a. tingitana (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003), S.a. splendens (Beukema et al. 2013), S.a. spelaea (Escoriza and Comas 2007), and S.a. algira (Bedriaga 1883).
The taxonomic validity of this species is disputed.
This form probably consists of at least three species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
The name Thorius minutissimus has been applied to populations at other localities, but these are now known to belong to other species in the genus (Hanken and Wake pers. comm.).
Records from further south in Tezonapa county (S. Rovito pers. obs. 2010, 2014, 2016) do not belong to this species (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019).
Populations attributed to this species from locations other than the type locality (Cerro San Felipe) need to be confirmed and are currently not included here.
This form might comprise more than one species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).

Bart et al. (1997) determined that the name Necturus alabamensis applies only to the waterdog in the upper Black Warrior River drainage. For years, the name had been mistakenly applied to a more common species of waterdog that occurs in the coastal plain. Further taxonomic revisions involving this species are likely (Petranka 1998). See Bart et al. (1997) for an account of the nomenclatural history of this and related species.
Rhyacotriton variegatus, R. kezeri and R. cascadae formerly were included in this species.
The conspecificity of the disjunct populations needs to be assessed.
Atoconeura aethiopica was formerly considered a subspecies of A. biordinata, but it is now regarded as a valid species (Dijkstra in prep.).

Until recently Ceragrion georgiferyi was considered a subspecies of Ceriagrion tenellum, but both male and female show distinct morphological characters and it is now considered to be a full species (Schneider 1986, Kalkman 2005).
Three subspecies have been described: Cordulegaster helladica helladica, C. h. buchholzi and C. h. kastalia.

The Java Stingaree is known only from the type specimen and is considered valid with the holotype housed at the Humboldt-Universität, Museum für Naturkunde, Zoologisches Museum, Berlin, Germany. It is a unique species of stingaree and its placement in the genus Urolophus is provisional (Last et al. 2016). It is the only known stingaree (family Urolophidae) from Java; the Kai Stingaree (Urolophus kaianus), the only other stingaree known from Indonesia, doesn't overlap with the historical range of the Java Stingaree (Last et al. 2016).

Previous studies of the family Gymnuridae have divided it into two genera based on the presence or absence of a dorsal fin; Aetoplatea with a dorsal fin and Gymnura without (Murdy et al. 1997, Compagno and Last 1999, Vossoughi and Vosoughi 1999, Oshigou et al. 2004, Yano et al. 2005). A recent taxonomic review of the Australian Butterfly Ray Gymnura australis (Ramsay and Ogilby 1886), supports the amalgamation of all species into a single genus; Gymnura (Jacobsen 2007). Jacobsen (2007) found that dorsal fin development in G. australis is variable and inconsistent with the two genus hypothesis, thus suggesting that Aeteoplata should be designated as a junior synonym.
This species is poorly represented in collections.
This species is considered distinct from Aetomylaeus milvus (Last et al. 2016).

The previous assessment of the Turks and Caicos Rock Iguana (Gerber 2004) recommended additional genetic studies to fully evaluate the subspecific designation of Cyclura carinata bartschi (Cochran 1931) on Booby Cay, located 0.5 km off the east end of Mayaguana Island, The Bahamas. Two independent population genetic studies have now demonstrated that iguanas on Booby Cay are not genetically different from C. carinata in the Turks and Caicos Islands, and therefore should not be considered as a separate subspecies (Bryan et al. 2007, Welch et al. 2017). Further, the Booby Cay population is genetically most similar to populations from the eastern side of the Caicos Bank, rather than the most geographically proximate populations on the western and northern sides of the Caicos Banks (Welch et al. 2017). Since it is likely that humans introduced iguanas to Booby Cay, this population is not included in the species’ extent of occurrence.

Welch et al. (2017) describe the existence of two distinct Evolutionary Significant Units (ESUs, sensu Moritz 1994) for C. carinata: one inhabiting islands on the western end of the Caicos Bank, and one inhabiting the remaining islands of the Caicos Bank and islands of the Turks Bank. Multiple management units (MUs) are also identified within each ESU (Welch et al. 2017). Considering the severe geographic and genetic fragmentation of iguanas across the archipelago these authors recommended the two ESUs be elevated as different subspecies.

Until recently this species was regarded as subspecies of Pyrrhosoma nymphula. Kalkman and Lopau (2006) illustrated the differences between the two taxa and confirmed that they should be treated as two full valid species.

Ris (1919) described Orthetrum poecilops poecilops from Guangdong. The subspecies Orthetrum poecilops miyajimaense Yuki & Doi, 1938 was described, originally as separate species, from Miyajima, a small island near Hiroshima, southern Honshu, Japan. Asahina and Sawano (1957) synonymised the two taxa but later Asahina (1970) reinstated miyajimaense at subspecies level, based principally on its smaller size. Wilson (2001) considers the two taxa are probably synonyms. Nevertheless the Japanese population represents a distinct and isolated (fragmented) population.
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.

Formerly, Boyeria cretensis was confused with—and regarded as a subpopulation of—Boyeria irene (Fonscolombe, 1838), but both species are clearly distinct (Boudot 1989, Peters 1991, Kohli et al. 2014).
Taxonomic status uncertain. Appears to be close to Aplocheilichthys maculatus Klausewitz, 1957.
Recent change from genus Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003). Squalius alburnoides transferred to Iberocypris (Kottelat and Freyhoff 2007)

authority: De Vos, Snoeks & Thys van den Audenaerde, 1991

taxonomicNotes: Initially included in Nemacheilus insignis, but valid as a separate species (M. Goren, pers. comm.).

Previously also reported as Tilapia jipe, T. (Sarotherodon) jipe, T. (Oreochromis) jipe and S. jipe (antiquated names). It also appears Oreochromis pangani is the same species as O. jipe (Snoeks pers. comm.).
Transferred from genus Pseudophoxinus to Telestes.
Recent change of genus from Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
Taxonomic distinction probably not obvious when compared with Lates niloticus.
Initially included in Nemacheilus insignis, but valid as a separate species (M. Goren, pers. comm.).
A revision of the genus Rutilus from southern Europe on morphological and molecular basis is in progress by Bianco P.G., Ketmaier, V. and Durand J.-Do.
It is considered sometimes only as a subspecies.
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.
The taxonomy of Barbatula is in need of revision.

The generic placement of this species has been discussed in the recent past and it is clear, that it is not a species of Pseudophoxinus, as considered by earlier authors. The relationships of the species is close to the genus Alburnus and Anaecypris. It was placed in Anaecypris by Geiger et al. (2014), an opinion followed here.  Indeed, Anaecypris is closely related to Alburnus.
Initially included in Nemacheilus insignis, but valid as a separate species (M. Goren, pers. comm.).
This species is closely related to the Acanthodactylus pardalis (Lichtenstein, 1823) complex.
Records of this species from Israel refer to Acanthodactylus beershebensis, and records from Jordan refer to A. ahmadisii (Y. Werner pers. comm). Records from Algeria refer to another species.

This species used to be considered as a subspecies of Chalcides polylepis, but it was separated as a full species by (Pasteur et al. 1988; Brown and Pestano 1998). According to López Jurado (1998), the International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature ruled that the valid name of this taxon is C. simonyi, and not C. occidentalis.
We follow Smith and Wallach (1994) in including this species in the monotypic genus Lycognathophis, rather than in Scopelophis, as proposed by Dowling (1990).
The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles.

The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles. Cheke (1984) has disputed the validity of Janetaescincus veseyfitzgeraldi. A taxonomic review is in progress (J. Gerlach pers. comm.).
This species is included in Hierophis following Utiger and Schätti (2004).
This species is included in Montivipera following Nilson et al. (1999).

Iberolacerta cyreni and Iberolacerta martinezricai are now separated as distinct species from Iberolacerta monticola (Mayer and Arribas 1996) and mitochondrial DNA (Mayer and Arribas 2003; Carranza et al. 2004a; Crochet et al. 2004). This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003). The population in the Montes de León has recently been described as a separate species, Iberolacerta galani (Arribas et al. 2006).

authority: Moravec, Baha El Din, Seligmann, Sivan & Werner, 1999

taxonomicNotes: Following the ruling of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, the name of this species is Gallotia bravoana, not Gallotia gomerana.
This species is described by Hernández et al. (2000), but the name first appeared in Barbadillo et al. (1999).

This taxon is now considered to be a full species based on evidence from Arribas (2001), Crochet et al. (2004), Mayer and Arribas (1996, 2003) and Odierna et al. (1996). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).

This taxon is considered to be a full species based on evidence from Arribas (1996), Carranza et al. (2004), Crochet et al. (2004), Mayer and Arribas (1996, 2003) and Odierna et al. (1996). It was formerly treated as a subspecies of Iberolacerta monticola. The specific status of this taxon is supported by morphology (Arribas 1996), allozymes (Mayer and Arribas 1996) and mitochondrial DNA (Mayer and Arribas 2003; Carranza et al. 2004a; Crochet et al. 2004). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).
Animals from Jordan might belong to a separate subspecies. More taxonomic work is needed on the fragmented populations of this species.

This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Iberolacerta monticola, but genetic and morphological data support a full specific rank (Mayer and Arribas 2003; Arribas and Carranza 2004; Crochet et al. 2004). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).

Both spellings (latastei and latasti) appeared in different places in the original description by Boscà and were subsequently used by different authors. David and Ineich (1999) acted as the first reviser and selected latastei as the valid spelling. However, the name is still under dispute (Montori and Llorente 2005), and is under discussion in the International Commission for Zoological Nomenclature (V. Pérez-Mellado pers. comm.). Populations in the Atlas mountains of Morocco, currently assigned to a separate species V. monticola, may in fact belong to this species (Brito et al. 2006).
The isolated eastern subpopulation in Montenegro has been proposed as a separate species (Ljubisavljevic et al. 2007).

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of Podarcis bocagei, but was raised to species rank (Sá-Sousa 2000a, Sá-Sousa and Harris 2002) based on genetic differences (see also: Harris et al. 2002; Harris and Sá-Sousa 2001, 2002; Pinho et al. 2003).

This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae but has recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae; Parathelphusidae is now regarded as a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae (Klause et al. in press).

This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae but has recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae; Parathelphusidae is now regarded as a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae (Klause et al. in press).

This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae but has recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae; Parathelphusidae is now regarded as a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae (Klause et al. in press).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Plectrohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae but has recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae; Parathelphusidae is now regarded as a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae (Klause et al. in press).

This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae but has recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae; Parathelphusidae is now regarded as a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae (Klause et al. in press).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Incilius coccifer by Mendelson et al. (2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

We follow Veith et al. (2003), in considering this species to be distinct from Rana macrocnemis at the species level. This species is confirmed through molecular data to occur in Çakıroluk (type locality) and Girdev Lake (U. Kaya pers. comm. December 2018).
This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken, Wake and Savage 2005).

This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken et al. 2005). This taxon is similar to B. nigresens and B. obscura and further studies are needed to fully resolve the taxonomy of this species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This species was separated from Lyciasalamandra luschani by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

Martin (1909) described this taxon as a subspecies of Calopteryx splendens (Harris, 1782) and was followed by several authors (Morton 1924, Schmidt 1954, Buchholtz 1955). Bartenef (1912) regarded it as a subspecies of Calopteryx syriaca Rambur, 1842. Although already Dumont (1975, 1977) treated the taxon - with some doubts - as a valid species, it was Schneider (1986) who could show conclusively that C. hyalina merits full specific rank: C. hyalina and C. syriaca are sympatric but never syntopic. In addition to sympatry (upper Orontes, Nahr al-Kabir (S), Litani, Lake Hula) they exhibit reproductive character displacement. Where C. hyalina comes into contact with C. intermedia Selys, 1887 (lower Orontes, Nahr al-Kabir (S)) hybrids occur, and these were described by Buchholtz (1955) as Calopteryx splendens "pseudosyriaca".
Often referred to as the synonyms Dipturus flavirostris or Raja flavirostris. Add Daniel Figueroa info about genetic differences between Atlantic and Pacific populations.

Prior to its description in 2006, this species was previously referred to as Rhinobatos sp. nov [Indonesia - white spotted].

This is a newly recognized species of Rhinobatos which is landed frequently in southern Bali, and also in other parts of eastern Indonesia, by gillnet fisherman. Differs markedly from the other co-occurring newly recognized species Rhinobatos jimbaranensis and also from other Rhinobatos species in this region.

Prior to its description in 2006, this species was referred to as Rhinobatos sp. nov. [Indonesia - blotched].

This newly recognised species of Rhinobatos is landed frequently in southern Bali by gillnet fisherman. It differs markedly from the other co-occurring newly recognised species of, Rhinobatos penggali and also from other Rhinobatos species in this region.

In 2004, Andrew Smith discovered a new species Poecilotheria hanumavilasumica from a sacred grove of the Hanumavilasum Temple on Rameshwaram Island. This species was earlier misidentified by Simon (1885), and Annandale (1907), as Poecilotheria fasciata from the Island and later Gravely (1915) misidentified this as Poecilotheria striata from Pamban on Rameshwaram Island.

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of Bactrian Camel under Camelus ferus, while the domestic form is considered under Camelus bactrianus (see Gentry et al. 2004).

Grubb (2005) lists ferus as a subspecies of bactrianus, contrary to most authors.

One-humped camels (Camelus dromedarius) and Bactrian camels (Camelus ferus) can produce viable hybrids (Camelus dromedarius hybridus J. Fischer 1829, unavailable), but hybrid males are thought to be sterile (A.P. Gray 1972).

Samples of skin taken from the remains of dead wild Bactrian Camels have been sent to scientists for genetic DNA testing. The results have been remarkable. Each skin sample has shown two or three distinct genetic differences to the domestic Bactrian camel and a 3% base difference. This answers the charge that the wild Bactrian camel is a domestic runaway.
