This species looks very similar to Hydrolagus lemures and partly overlaps in range although H. ogilbyi is reported to occur in shallower waters and may grow to larger sizes (Last and Stevens 1994). However, data from the study of large collections of H. lemures and H. ogilbyi indicate a much larger overlap in range, both geographic and bathymetric, and size than indicated by Last and Stevens (1994). If H. ogilbyi is indeed restricted in range as indicated by Last and Stevens (1994, 2009), then the large number of records of H. ogilbyi from the Great Australian Bight and Western Australia may be misidentifications. Colour is a primary feature for identification, however it appears to be quite variable within both species and these two species are easily mistaken. Due to the confusion with regard to identification of H. ogilbyi and H. lemures, a closer examination these two species is recommended to determine species distinctions.

Reference to H. ogilbyi from Japan (Tanaka 1908) is probably erroneous and likely a misidentification of Chimaera phantasma.

The previously monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated in 2009 with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Giant Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018)

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Reef Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in mis-identifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.
Scymnodon plunketi may be a junior synonym of Scymnodon macracanthus (Regan 1906) (White et al. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is required.

Rhynchobatus australiae is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

Revision of Squalus in the Indo-Australasian region resulted in the resurrection of S. montalbani (Philippines, Indonesia, Australia) and S. griffini (New Zealand) and the description of S. chloroculus Last, White & Motomura, 2007. These species were previously considered to be conspecific with S. mitsukurii, which this work has revealed, does not occur in Australasian waters. Continued investigation of Squalus mitsukurii from around the world is resulting in more taxa being recognized.

Squalus montalbani was previously considered a likely junior synonym of S. mitsukurii but was resurrected as a valid species by Last et al. (2007). Referred to as Squalus sp. 1 in White et al. (2006a).
Formerly, U. asperrimus was the only species within Urogymmus. Last et al. (2016) added five more species to the genus.
Appears to hybridize with the Banded Stingaree (Urolophus cruciatis) at the southern end of its range. Further information is required to assess the validity of this species (Last et al. 2016).
Synonyms = Unio cariosa Say, 1817; Unio crocatus Lea, 1841.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.

Liolaemus stolzmanni is a member of a poorly-characterized radiation of species whose systematics have long been complicated by restricted access to the remote areas where these lizards occur (Langstroth 2011). Confusion has surrounded the correct attribution of records from northern Chile and adjacent regions of Argentina, Bolivia and Peru) to either Liolaemus stolzmanni or Liolaemus reichei, the oldest available names for taxa from this region, due to inadequacies in or misunderstandings of the original descriptions by subsequent authors (Langstroth 2011). This situation was further complicated by the descriptions of multiple additional taxa from Chile, Peru and Bolivia, with several specimens previously reported as L. reichei being properly attributable to L. poconchilensis and Bolivian material described as L. stolzmanni having been referred to L. pachecoi (Langstroth 2011). Examining photographs of the type series of L. stolzmanni, Langstroth (2011) synonymized L. reichei (as now understood, a species restricted to northern Chile) with this older name and proposed emending the type locality from "Hoch-Peru" to "Deserts of Iquique, Tarapaca Region, Chile", on the basis that this species is not known to occur anywhere within the territory of modern Peru and indeed appears to be endemic to this area of northern Chile.

Generic status of Puntius chelynoides is under debate. Talwar and Jhingran (1991) have considered this species as Tor chelynoides while Jayaram (1999) and Menon (1999) have considered this species as Naziritor chelynoides.
Puntius denisonii was described by Day (1865) from Mundakkayam, Kerala, southern India.

Menon, Rema and Vishwanath (2000) described this species (as Puntius manipurensis) from Loktak Lake, Manipur, India. This species considered as valid by Kullander and Fang (2005), Vishwanath and Laishram (2004), Kullander and Britz (2008).

Jerdon described this species from Srirangapattana in 1849 as Systomus arulius. Subsequently, the species was reported from Kottayam, Thenmalai, Kulathupuzha and Periyar Lake (Menon 1999). However, a new species, Dawkinsia exclamatio was later described from Thenmalai and Kulathupuzha as a different species (Pethiyagoda and Kottelat 2005). But Knight et al. (2011) speculates that D. exclamatio are possible hybrids between D. arulius with D. filamentosa. Since there are no recent records of D. arulius from either Kallada or Periyar there is a need to check for existing voucher specimens if any, to validate the historic occurrence (and their later extirpation) of the species in this region.
Sahyadria chalakkudiensis was described (as Puntius chalakkudiensis) by Menon, Remadevi and Thobias (1999) from the Chalakudy River, Kerala, India.
This species most probably represents a senior synonym of Demirsoyus salmani Sirin and Ciplak, 2004 in Yalim et al. (2004) (F. Willemse pers. comm. 2005).
This species is considered to possibly represent a local form of C. dorsalis by Willemse (1984). Taxonomic research is necessary to clarify the status of this species.

The large gap between the northern and southern subpopulations and the high degree of long-term isolation in different mountain ranges suggest a considerable infraspecific variability which requires detailed taxonomic research.

This species was transferred to Dawkinsia following Pethiyagoda et al. (2012). Dawkinsia tambraparniei was described as Puntius arulius tambraparniei from Tambraparini River, Tamil Nadu by Silas (1954). The species status was validated by Pethiyagoda and Kottelat (2005) in their revision of the Puntius filamentosus complex.

The Horrid Ground-weaver (Nothophantes horridus Merrett & Stevens, 1995) is a recently described species of small linyphiid spider (total body length of just 2.5 mm). It is also the only known representative of the genus.
The taxonomy and distribution of Pithecia follows the revision by Marsh (2014).

Georg Marcgrave (1648) described a capuchin monkey from the northeastern Atlantic Forest of Brazil as "caitaia". This monkey had bright yellow long fur, a rounded head and a not prominent forehead. At least three names have been used for this primate species: Simia flavia Schreber 1774, Cebus flavus Geoffroy 1812 and Cebus apella libidinosus (Spix 1823). Until recently, specimens of Simia flavia did not exist in scientific collections. For this reason the animal depicted in plate 31-b of Schreber (1774) had never been properly identified. A specimen collected in the state of Pernambuco, Brazil was considered the neotype of Simia flavia Schreber, 1774 and was named Cebus flavius (Schreber, 1774) (Oliveira and Langguth 2006). There is a junior synonym: Cebus queirozi (Pontes et al. 2006).

Silva Jr (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the un-tufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera: Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the un-tufted group; and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 for the tufted capuchins.

Taxonomy of the tufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) follows Silva Jr (2001), who did not recognise any subspecific forms. Groves (2001, 2005) presented an alternative taxonomy for the tufted capuchins as follows: C. apella apella Linnaeus, 1758; C. apella fatuellus Linnaeus, 1766; C. apella macrocephalus Spix, 1823; C. apella peruanus Thomas, 1901; C. apella tocantinus Lönnberg, 1939; C. apella margaritae Hollister, 1914; C. libidinosus libidinosus Spix, 1823; C. libidinosus pallidus Gray, 1866; C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829; C. libidinosus juruanus Lönnberg, 1939; C. nigritus nigritus Goldfuss, 1809; C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820; C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823; C. xanthosternos Wied-Neuwied, 1826 (see Fragaszy et al. 2004; Rylands et al. 2005).

Groves (2001) listed three subspecific forms for C. nigritus: C. nigritus nigritus Goldfuss, 1809; C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820, considered a distinct species by Silva Jr. (2001); and C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823, considered a junior synonym of C. nigritus by Silva Jr. (2001).

The species was transferred to Sapajus (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012).

Silva Jr (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera. Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the untufted group, and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 is the name available for the tufted capuchins. 
With a unique karyotype (Seuánez et al. 1986) and evidence for relatively early divergence from other Sapajus species (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012; Nascimento et al. 2015), Sapajus xanthosternos is considered a distinct species based on morphological characteristics by both Groves (2001, 2005) and Silva Jr. (2001).

Cebus leucocephalus Gray, 1865, Colombia, restricted by P. Hershkovitz in 1949 to El Tambor, Rio Labrija, 25 km north-west of Bucaramanga, Santander, Colombia. Recent molecular study based on mitochondrial markers however, showed that Cebus leucocephalus and C. adustus are not distinct enough to comprise different taxa. Further studies including more samples as well as more genetic markers would be necessary to confirm that these two taxa are synonyms. If confirmed that adustus is the same taxon as leucocephalus, leucocephalus would be the senior synonym. Thus, C. leucocephlus taxonomic status and distribution remains uncertain.

Carcharhinus tjutjot is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).
The two distinct subpopulations of this species are currently considered two subspecies but they may actually be two separate species (P. Fontana pers. comm. 2015).

The subspecies Alsophis antiguae sajdaki is thought by some to represent a full species (Hedges et al. 2009), which would render A. antiguae extinct. There is however evidence against this proposition from a study of more than 400 live specimens from Great Bird Island which concluded that, apart from some geographical variation in ventral counts, the proposed diagnostic characters represented sexual dimorphism. On this basis this account considers that A. antiguae is still extant, represented by the surviving form A. a. sadjaki (J. Daltry pers. comm. 2010, 2015).

There are currently two recognized subspecies:
A. hyporissor hyporissor
A. hyporissor leberi.

Two subspecies are recognized:
S. torrei spielmani Grant, 1958
S. torrei torrei Barbour, 1914.

Helgen et al. (2009) suggested that two different species were previously considered as 'Mountain Coati' N. olivacea; one endemic to Colombia and Ecuador, N. olivacea, and one restricted to Venezuela, N. meridensis.

Mivart (1890) distinguished two species of Cuon, the northern Dhole (C. alpinus) and the southern Dhole (C. javanicus), based on differences in body size and the second upper and second lower molars. Dholes were later recognized as a single species (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1966), but separated into as many as 11 subspecies based on differences in coat length and colour (Durbin et al. 2004). The validity of many of these subspecies is doubtful, and a genetics study found no clear subspecies distinctions (Iyengar et al. 2005). However, samples used by Iyengar et al. (2005) came exclusively from the southern half of the Dhole distribution, so the genetic distinctiveness between northern and southern Dholes remains unknown. Examination of the auditory bulla showed at least one northern subspecies, from the Tian Shan Mountains, to be morphologically distinct from other subspecies (Ivanoff 2007). Further research is needed to clarify the morphological and genetic differences between northern and southern dholes, especially because conservation efforts would need to employ different strategies for the two groups, as they occupy vastly different habitats and prey on different species.

The putative northern-Dhole group historically occurred throughout East Asia to as far south as the Himalayan Mountains and the Yangtze River, and would include the following five subspecies described by Durbin et al. (2004): C. a. alpinus, C. a. primaevus, C. a. laniger, C. a. hesperius, and C. a. fumosus. The putative southern-dhole group would include the remaining six subspecies described by Durbin et al. (2004): C. a. lepturus, C. a. dukhumensis, C. a. adjustus, C. a. infuscus, C. a. sumatrensis, and C. a. javanicus. Within the southern-Dhole group, Iyengar et al. (2005) found two major phylogeographic genetic groupings on the mainland, and stated that the subspecific status of Dholes on Sumatra and Java was unclear and requires further study.
This species was originally described from pre-Hispanic and subfossil remains. It was subsequently discovered alive (Wetzel et al. 1975; Wetzel 1977a, b, 1981).
The status of the two subspecies needs to be studied as these may represent unique species.

Bawean Deer has sometimes been included in Hog Deer Axis porcinus (Haltenorth 1963), but is better considered a full species (Groves and Grubb 1987, Grubb 2005). With Hog Deer it was often placed in the genus Cervus (e.g. Chasen 1940, van Bemmel 1944), until Groves and Grubb (1987) strongly argued for placement in Axis. The most recent analyses indicate that these two species, together with calamianensis, constitute a genus distinct from Axis, Hyelaphus (Meijaard and Groves 2004, Pitra et al. 2004). The species name is sometimes mis-spelled kuhli, but the correct original spelling, which must be used today, is kuhlii.

authority: Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014
Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014
Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014

taxonomicNotes: It is possible that this species could be a taxonomic complex, however the current data cannot confirm this (Guayasamin et al., 2015).
The status of the subspecies Asiotmethis t. steppensis and A. t. flavipes needs to be studied.
The former French subspecies Prionotropis hystrix rhodanica and Prionotropis hystrix azami are now considered valid species (Massa et al. 2015).
A recent study by López et al. (2013) showed that the former records from North Lanzarote and Montaña Clara belong to a different species, Purpuraria magna.

A female record from Troglav Mountain is quite similar to what is regarded as R. buchichii in the literature. However, the true identity is uncertain as far as the subpopulation from Troglav and the subpopulations from islands are not compared morphologically on both sexes and bioacoustically, both on song characters and stridulatory area morphology.
This is a split from the broader concept of Phrynobatrachus steindachneri (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
There are two subspecies: Podisma carpetana ignatii Morales-Agacino, 1950, and Podisma carpetana carpetana.
This species has been moved from the genus Jacobsiella Harz, 1975 to the genus Sphingonotus Fieber, 1852 by Husemann et al. (2013).

Wallach et al. (2014) follow Henderson and Powell (2009) in recognizing Boa orophias and B. nebulosa as full species, however, some other authors (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2015) still treat both as subspecies of Boa constrictor.
This species was changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Conacinotus by Barat (2012).
This species was moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).
The species was moved from the genus Ephippigerida Bolívar, 1903 by Barat (2012),

Hecht (1951) treated Aristelliger nelsoni as a subspecies of A. praesignis in a distribution map of the species' range but provided no supporting justification. This scheme has nonetheless been widely followed since, although distinct morphological differences between A. nelsoni and the nominate form were highlighted by Bauer and Russell (1993). McCranie (2018) corroborated this finding, and noted that the deep sea separating the Swan Islands from the Cayman Islands and Jamaica further supports the recognition of the two taxa as distinct species. This author recommended treating A. nelsoni as a full species pending molecular research to clarify its status, a recommendation that had previously been followed by Powell and Henderson (2012). On this basis, and noting that the proposed subspecific status has never been adequately justified, this account follows McCranie (2015, 2018) in treating A. nelsoni as a full species.

Records from Hellshire have been sequenced and identified as a separate, undescribed species (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data), confirming that Tropidophis stullae is known only from Portland Ridge and likely to be endemic to this area.

Even though the species was considered as part of the Faviidae, this affiliation has been considered dubious and the species has most recently been placed within Caryophylliidae (Romano and Cairns 2000, Cairns et al. 2001) and now within Scleractinia incertae sedis (Hoeksema and Cairns 2013).

The Spanish subpopulations of Orculella bulgarica have been assigned by Arrébola et al. (2012) to a separate species O. aragonica Westerlund, 1897, closely allied to O. bulgarica. This separation was based on anatomical (mostly by the particular structure of the penial caecum) and molecular differences, although they are sibling species in shell morphology. Only one subpopulation from Turkey was included in this study. The incorporation of more samples of O. bulgarica from different localities, and particularly DNA sequences of O. bulgarica lamellata, could give more information about the singularities of the Spanish subpopulations.

F. Welter-Schultes argues in AnimalBase (http://www.animalbase.org/ accessed 17.03.2016) that the name Orcula dolium f. aragonica Westerlund, 1897 used by Arrébola et al. (2012) could be unavailable without providing evidence that the name had been used for a species or subspecies before 1985 (Art. 45.6.4.1).

There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.
This species was recently found to belong in the genus Anhydrophryne rather than Arthroleptella (Dawood and Stam 2006).
A question hangs over the taxonomic significance of disjunct populations of this species (A. Channing pers. comm.).
This species is closely related to Afrixalus spinifrons (Cope 1862). Species boundaries in this complex are uncertain and taxonomic studies using calls, morphology and genetics are necessary.
The relationships between this and other species without toe discs requires a detailed taxonomic study using molecular and morphological methodologies.
A deep genetic split characterises the disjunct distribution of this species.
This is a restricted concept of A. opisthomelas following the split of the broader concept into this and A. cassidyhornae (Amézquita et al. 2013).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Bidau 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14781,"3":{"1":0,"3":1},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica Neue","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Bidau 2015).
The species needs taxonomic revision (O. Lessa pers. comm.)
Known as Tympanoctomys loschalchalerosorum (Dunnum 2015).
Reviewed by Gromov and Erbajeva (1995) and Shenbrot et al. (1995).

Rulyrana saxiscandens, Cochranella croceopodes and Rulyrana tangarana are considered to be synonymous based on available morphological, bioacoustic, and phylogenetic evidence (Twomey et al. 2014). Under the Principle of the First Reviser of the ICZN (article 24.2.2) precedence is given to saxiscandens, rendering R. tangarana and C. croceopodes junior synonyms of R. saxiscandens.

This taxon is a complex currently under revision. Records of this species from Anjanaharibe and Tsaratanana (Raxworthy et al. 1998), Andringitra (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996), and Ambolokopatrika (Andreone et al. 2000) are highly likely to refer to other species, e.g. R. ornata, R. tany, R. vaventy and other undescribed species (Scherz et al. 2014). In the framework of ongoing revision of the Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014, 2015), all available specimens of this complex in European and Malagasy collections have been examined and found only a single specimen was found to correspond to the R. serratopalpebrosa holotype and it is thus considered to be restricted to Marojejy. For this reason, we exclude all uncertain records of this species (F. Glaw and M.D. Scherz pers. comm. November 2015). Records from further south in Madagascar might refer to Plethodontohyla coronata.
Morgan (1997) named the species "in respect of Ellen Clark’s pioneering parastacid studies".
Eupsophus altor has been synonymised with this species by Correa-Quezada et al. (2017).

authority: Veloso, Sallaberry A., Navarro, Iturra-C., Valencia, Penna & Díaz, 1982

taxonomicNotes: There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.

Its tadpole was briefly described as belonging to Telmatobius montanus (Cei and Roig 1965), but was later re-assigned as this species (Cei 1976).

There may be an additional subpopulation of this species occurring 60 km south of the Pehuenche Valley, Cajón de Plaza in Chile (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). Mitochondrial sequences identify these individuals as belonging to both this species and Alsodes hugoi, despite resembling this species (Correa et al. 2018). It may be a hybrid population, however further taxonomic work is required to confirm its identity (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, it has not been included within this species' distribution map.

It is possible that Argentinean subpopulations of Alsodes from the forests of Neuquén and Río Negro Provinces might belong to A. verrucosus, although until this can be verified these records have not been included in attempts to map its range.

authority: Formas, Northland, Capetillo, Nuñez, Cuevas & Brieva, 1999
taxonomicNotes: The species may be a synonym of T. vilamensis (Sáez et al., 2014).
May be a synonym of T. dankoi (Sáez et al. 2014).

Diagnosis of Telmatobius chusmisensis is based on external morphology and osteology of adults, external morphology of tadpoles, karyotype, chromosomal C-banded patterns and Ag-NOR (nucleolar organizer region) position (Formas et al. 2006).

The species was identified by Ng (2002) after it was realized that the type series of crabs described as Karstama emdi (Ng and Whitten 1995) contained this additional species. The species was reassigned from Sesarmoides to Karstama by Davie and Ng (2007).

The species was redefined by Ng (2002) when a second species, K. balicum, was recognized from within the original type material, and the species was reassigned from genus Sesarmoides to Karstama by Davie and Ng (2007).
This species is now in the genus Phanogomphus.

authority: Boubli, da Silva, Amado, Herbk, Pontual & Farias, 2008
taxonomicNotes: The taxonomy of this newly described species follows Boubli et al. (2008).

To date there have been only preliminary and non-conclusive molecular genetic assessments of Cebus aequatorialis (Boubli et al. 2012; Ruiz-García et al. 2010), and so its provisional status as a species is based on its geographic isolation from other Cebus albifrons populations and its unique morphological characteristics such as pelage coloration. Jack and Campos (2012) suggest elevating C. aequatorialis to species level following the phylogenetic species concept.

The taxonomy of untufted capuchin monkeys (Cebus spp.) has recently been debated and although there is a better understanding of its phylogeny, some phylogenetic and biogeographical aspects of this genus remain unresolved (Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2010; Boubli et al. 2012; Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012). The Santa Marta white-fronted capuchin (Cebus malitiosus) comprises of all populations of untufted capuchins that occur in the north-western region of the Sierra Nevada de San Marta, in northern Colombia (Defler 2003, 2004). Both Hershkovitz (1949) and Hernadez-Camacho and Cooper (1976) consider the Santa Marta white-fronted capuchin a subspecies of C. albifrons, while Groves (2001) considers it as one of the six forms of varied white-fronted capuchins (Cebus albifrons versicolor) in northern Colombia. The only molecular study that has included a single sample of capuchin monkeys from the northern region of Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta found that C. malitiosus had a completely different haplotype compared to those from other northern Colombian populations (C. a. versicolor, C. a. pleei and C. a. cesarae) and actually nested in a basal branch with capuchin monkeys from the Colombian and Peruvian Amazon (Ruiz-García et al. 2010). The validity of C. malitiosus as a separate species on the northwestern foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta still needs further validation.

The taxonomy of untufted capuchin monkeys (Cebus spp.) has recently been debated and although there is a better understanding of its phylogeny, some phylogenetic and biogeographical aspects of this genus remain unresolved (Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2010; Boubli et al. 2012; Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012). The varied white-fronted capuchin (Cebus versicolor) currently comprises all populations of untufted capuchins that occur in northern Colombia, east of the Magdalena River and in the middle Magdalena River valley, excluding those populations on the western slope of the Eastern Andes and east of the eastern Andes Mountains (Cebus leucocephalus). Thus, C. versicolor includes several taxa proposed by Hershkovitz [1949] and reviewed by Hernandez-Camacho and Cooper (1976): C. albifrons versicolor from the Cauca-Magdalena interfluvium, C. a. cesarae in northern Cesar and north to the Rio Ranchería, and C. a. pleei from Mompos in Bolivar as regional variants (Boubli et al. 2012).  Ruiz-García et al. (2010) also found that C. a. versicolor, C. a. cesarae, and C. a. pleei were genetically closely related to one another.

There is no evident geographic barrier between C. versicolor and C. leucocephalus nor between C. versicolor and C. malitiosus and as proposed by Boubli et al. (2012), the validity of C. malitiosus as a separate species on the northwestern foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta still needs further validation (but see Ruiz-García et al. 2010).

Sousa plumbea has been recognized as a species since taxonomic revision of the genus Sousa in 2014 (Committee on Taxonomy 2014, Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014). Previously this species was lumped with the Indo-pacific Humpback dolphin (Sousa chinensis) but animals occurring in the Indian Ocean from South Africa to India are now recognized as taxonomically distinct from those that occur further east, based on genetics, skeletal morphology, external morphology and colour. There is uncertainty about the taxonomic affinities of the humpback dolphins that occur in the Bay of Bengal and future studies will confirm whether S. plumbea actually occurs east of the southern tip of India.

Previous formal taxonomy of this genus recognized the existence of only two species: S. teuszii in the Atlantic Ocean and S. chinensis in the Indo-Pacific Oceans (Committee on Taxonomy-Society for Marine Mammalogy 2009). However, recent morphological and molecular studies have shown the genus is composed of four species including: S. teuszii (Atlantic Ocean), S. plumbea (Indian Ocean), S. chinensis (eastern Indian and western Pacific Oceans) and a newly described species S. sahulensis found in the waters of the Sahul Shelf from northern Australia to southern New Guinea (Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014, Mendez et al. 2013).

The Australian Humpback Dolphin can be visually differentiated from the other species of the genus by the following combination of morphological characters: 1) the body is typically more dark grey in colour, 2) a diagonal cape line running from just above the eye and neck down to the urogenital area separates the dark back and lighter belly, 3) dorsal fin is lower in size, triangular in shape, and has a wide base without a visible dorsal hump and 4) white scarring and dark flecking on the head, back, dorsal fin, and tail stock are common in adult animals (Jefferson & Rosenbaum 2014). Seven diagnostic mtDNA characters and a single nuDNA character distinguish Sousa sahulensis from other species in the genus.

Morgan (1997) named Euastacus dharawalus after the Dharawal aboriginal language, but did not designate an official common name. However, he did refer to specimens of Riek’s crayfish in the Australian Museum collection as Fitzroy Falls Crayfish. The common name Fitzroy Falls Crayfish has been used ever since. There are no recent taxonomic changes or doubts as to the species validity.

The first individuals of this species were sampled in 1901 by S.E. Meek and F.E. Lutz from La Barca, Ocotlán, but at this time regarded as Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis. It lasted until the late 1990's and early 2000's when it become likely, that the stocks from the western distribution range of this species belong to a distinct one (Webb 1998, Doadrio and Domínguez 2004). Then in 2008, Domínguez-Domínguez et al. described Zoogoneticus purhepechus from individuals they collected in the Presa Verduzco (La Luz spring) at Jacona de Plancarte. They large distribution area and different populated drainages are the reason for distinguishing seven subpopulations of the La Luz Splitfin: The Lower Río Lerma subpopulation (type subpopulation) including the Río Duero, the Laguna Chapala/ Río Grande de Santiago subpopulation, the Laguna Magdalena subpopulation, the Upper Río Ameca subpopulation, the Laguna de Sayula subpopulation, the Laguna de Zapotlán subpopulation and the Laguna San Marcos subpopulation, including the lagunas San Marcos, Zacoalcos and Atotonilco.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. chathamensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

Pritchard (1996) restricted the name chathamensis to the now-extirpated tortoise populations of southwestern and central San Cristóbal, but excluded the eastern San Cristóbal population, considering this population to represent a possibly distinct subspecies for which no name was available. For purposes of this Red List Assessment, the eastern San Cristóbal population is considered part of chathamensis until taxonomic clarity emerges.

Testudo wallacei Rothschild, 1902, was described with type locality “Chatham Island?”, but its type locality was designated Jervis Island [Rábida] by Van Denburgh (1914); Rábida tortoises were hypothesized to be an introduced population (Pritchard 1996), later confirmed by genetic analysis (Poulakakis et al. 2012) to represent tortoises from southern Isabela, and the name wallacei is considered a nomen dubium and synonym of C. vicina (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2014).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra, as did several authors (Pritchard 1996; Caccone et al. 1999; Beheregaray et al. 2003; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980; Fritts 1983; Ernst and Barbour 1989) and more recently several researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) have treated most of them as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. darwini as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. hoodensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. porteri as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The name C. porteri now refers only to the species of tortoise found on western Santa Cruz Island in the area known as La Reserva (the originally designated Tortoise Reserve). A second tortoise species on eastern Santa Cruz Island from the Cerro Fatal region has recently been described as C. donfaustoi (Poulakakis et al. 2015), thus separating what was formerly considered one species into two. A third very small group of tortoises occurs in the northwestern region of Santa Cruz near Cerro Montura. The tortoises found at Cerro Montura have been identified as genetically indistinguishable from the Pinzón tortoise, C. duncanensis (Russello et al. 2005), and it is considered that they were probably introduced from Pinzón to Santa Cruz by humans.

Some recent literature suggests that the valid name for the Western Santa Cruz tortoise may be C. nigrita (e.g., EMBL database). However, the Tortoise and Freshwater Turtle Specialist Group follows the nomenclature of Pritchard (1996), Fritz and Havas (2007), TTWG (2014), and TEWG (2015), who concluded that nigrita is a nomen dubium and placed it in questionable synonymy under C. porteri.

There is unpublished morphological and genetic data supporting the suggestion by Cogger (2014) that the Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Islands populations represent distinct species (D. Chapple pers. comm. 2017). Until this work is formally published, this account retains the traditional concept of Christinus guentheri.

Recent genetic analysis indicates that disjunct records from the Monaro Tablelands in New South Wales represent a distinct population (Scott and Keogh 2000, Melville et al. 2007), but no formal taxonomic action has yet been taken. Records from the Darling Downs in Queensland have been described as the distinct species Tympanocryptus condaminensis (Melville et al. 2014).

The name Tympanocryptis condaminensis was erected by Melville et al. (2014) for the subpopulation of T. pinguicolla found in the Darling Downs, on the basis of genetic evidence that the two taxa are specifically distinct.

Parabotia curtus was originally described as Cobitis curta by Temminck & Schlegel (1846). After changes in the generic position, the species is included in Parabotia in the latest references. Because the gender of Parabotia is determined as masculine (see Kottelat 2012), Parabotia curtus (not curta) is currently used. Parabotia curtus is undoubtedly endemic to Japan, although an uncertain record of this species exists from southern China (see Watanabe et al. 2009). The species is included in the subfamily Botiinae of the family Cobitidae. Some recent references use the family name of Botiidae, based on the morphology and molecular phylogeny (e.g., Nalbant 2002, Šlechtová et al. 2006, Watanabe et al. 2009).
Genetic studies are in need for confirmation of the conspecificity of the Omanian (U. thomasi) and Somalian (U. t. aethiopica) populations.

The relationship between this species and Boophis microtympanum has not yet been clarified. Boophis laurenti might simply be a colour morph, but a distinct call has been recorded. More species could be involved, and the whole complex needs revision (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).

Molecular data indicate the existence of at least two different management units for conservation in this species, corresponding to the north and south of its distribution range (Andreone et al. 2006, Vieites et al. 2006).

This species and Mantella milotympanum might be colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm.). Populations with intermediate characteristics between Mantella crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004).

Records of Mantella expectata or M. betsileo from the arid west and southwest Madagascar (including from from Tsingy de Bemaraha) probably refer to a separate, undescribed, species that is not characterized by blue legs (F. Andreone pers. comm., Rabemananjara et al. 2007). Here we consider as Mantella expectata to refer only the populations from Isalo and the thin band further south (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species is genetically very closely related to Mantella baroni (Vences et al. 2004).
This species is closely related to Mantella pulchra (F. Glaw pers. comm.).

This species and Mantella crocea might represent colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm. August 2016, Chiari et al. 2004). Subpopulations with intermediate characteristics between M. crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004).
This species was redefined, and two new species, Mantidactylus charlotteae and M. zipperi, were described by Vences and Glaw (2004).

This species belongs to the Gephyromantis asper group and was split from it prior to its first assessment in 2004. The population from Manongarivo is genetically distinct (F. Glaw pers.comm. November 2015).

This recently described species is similar to Spinomantis peraccae and S. elegans. There is confustion regarding the taxonomy of this Group (additional species might be involved), and a revision is needed.
This species was revised by Glaw and Vences (2001) who described two sibling species: Gephyromantis tandroka and G. tschenki.
Records from Tsingy de Bemaraha now refer to Gephyromantis atsingy, records from Analavelona and the Kelifely Plateau are in need of confirmation (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).

This species was revised by Vences et al. (2002).

It was described from Nosy Be Island over 100 years ago and never seen there again (many species have Nosy Be as their type locality because an important port was situated there, but those species never actually occurred on the island and this record of G. horridus was suspected to one such mistake; however, the natural history museum in Vienna traced a specimen collected by Brancsik in 1890 from the island confirming that the species actually occured on Nosy Be (Glaw and Vences 2011).
The taxonomic distinction between Mantidactylus madecassus and M. pauliani has recently been corroborated on the basis of genetic studies (M. Vences pers. comm.).

The specific name was emended to massorum by Vences et al. (2003). However, according to Amphibian Species of the World version 5.2, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2008: http://research.amnh.org/herpetology/amphibia/index.php).
This species is here considered to belong to the genus Spinomantis, rather than Boophis, following Glaw and Vences (2006).
This species was previously included in Gephyromantis malagasius (Vences et al. 2002).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Mantidactylus biporus by Glaw and Vences (1999) and tentatively redefined by Glaw and Vences (2007). However, additional candidate species have been identified by Vieites et al. (2009) demonstrating that the taxonomic identity of the species is still uncertain and in need of further revision. Candidate species from the subgenus Brygoomantis (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This is likely to represent a species complex (C. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
It is not clear that the populations on the mainland of Madagascar belong to the same species as those on Nosy Be and Nosy Komba (M. Vences, F. Glaw, F. Andreone and C.J. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
Scaphiophryne spinosa has been separated from this species by Vences et al. (2003). The western subpopulations have also been separated as S. menabensis (Glos et al. 2005).

This species was synonymized with Stumpffia psologlossa by Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc (1991). However, we follow Glaw and Vences (1994) in treating it as a separate species. D'Cruze et al. (2007) recorded Stumpffia cf. roseifemoralis from Montagne des Français; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in removing this species from the synonymy of Mantidactylus brevipalmatus.
Anodonthyla vallani was recognised as a distinct species by Vences et al. (2010), having previously been confused with A. nigrigularis.
This species has been split from the broader concept of Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014).

authority: Klages, Glaw, Köhler, Müller, Hipsley & Vences, 2013
Glaw, Vallan, Andreone, Edmonds, Dolch & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015

taxonomicNotes: We follow Pickersgill (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Afrixalus uluguruensis. However, molecular data show that this might represent more than one species (S. Loader pers. comm. Oct 2015).

Pickersgill (2000, 2005) considers this form to be a subspecies of Afrixalus stuhlmanni, with which it hybridizes as forests are cleared. We follow Schiøtz (1999, and pers. comm.) in considering it to be a valid species. However, we follow Pickersgill (2005) and K. Howell (pers. comm.) in considering it to occur in the coastal areas of Tanzania, as well as in the Shimba Hills in Kenya.

This taxon is now considered to be a full species based on evidence from Arribas (1999), Crochet et al. (2004), Mayer and Arribas (1996, 2003) and Odierna et al. (1996). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).

The Leptolalax heteropus-solus complex has not been fully resolved and, due to morphological similarities, further genetic work is required to verify the identity of all Peninsular Malaysia records and determine its' true distribution (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

authority: A. Reischütz, N. Reischütz & P.L. Reischütz, 2012

taxonomicNotes:
Most 19th and 20th century sources placed the Sambar in the genus Cervus, as C. unicolor, but Grubb (1990) resurrected the genus Rusa for this and allied species. This was followed by Groves (2003) and Grubb (2005). Groves (2006) pointed out that Chinese Sambar has not traditionally been separated, even at a subspecific level, from Indomalayan R. u. equinus, despite karyotype differences (Groves and Grubb 1987) and some clear pelage differences, indicating that taxonomic revision may be forthcoming. Later still Groves and Grubb (2011) divided Sambar into two species, Southeast Asian Sambar C. equinus of SE Asia (including NE India) and southern China, and residual Indian Sambar C. unicolor of South Asia, based on a variety of morphological differences (no mention was made of ‘Chinese Sambar’). They gave no sample sizes or information on animals in the area where the two forms abut, making it difficult to assess the validity of the proposal. This warrants priority investigation because the distributions of the two species mean that the western form is relatively secure, with large subpopulations in many well-managed protected areas, whereas the eastern form has very few apparently secure subpopulations and would, if assessed separately, warrant a Red List Category at least one level more threatened than that for the western form.


Throughout at least Indochina there is a predictable flow of reports of ‘novel’ variation in large deer, with the implication that a new species may be involved (e.g. Pham Trong Anh et al. 1996 and, particularly, surveys through local people by overseas consultants); these stem from Sambar (often young animals) with unbranched antlers.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was mistakenly reported as Pristimantis cabrerai by Kattan (1984).
Lynch (1996b) notes misidentifications in earlier accounts.

Records from the western slope of the Serranía de los Paraguas in Chocó Department and Valle de Cauca Department (Castro-Herrera and Vargas-Salinas 2008) might actually refer to another species, P. molybrignus (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018), and therefore are excluded from this species' extent of occurrence (EOO) until further taxonomic work is carried out.
Following genetic and morphological studies, this species was moved from Pristimantis to the newly described Tachiramantis (Heinicke et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This is the sister species of Pristimantis bellona according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996b).
According to the original description, some records of Pristimantis cruentus from western Colombia and western Ecuador might actually be this species.

Due to a typographic error on the title of the paper describing this species (Lynch 1995), the name was given as P. lasallorum. However, the correct spelling is P. lasalleorum. Lynch (1995) gives the correct spelling elsewhere in the original description.
This taxon has previously been confused with Pristimantis calcaratus (Lynch 1998). It was previously assessed under the name Pristimantis kelephas; this was an incorrect subsequent spelling.
Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007) noted that this species may occur in Ecuador.

Given the morphological similarity of Nymphargus garciae with N. nephelophila and N. oreonympha, it is possible that they are the same species with phenotypic geographic variation (Guayasamín et al. 2018).
Named as Cochranella punctulata by Ruiz-Carranza and Linch in 1995, the genus has then been reviewed and replaced with Sachatamia by Guayasamin et al. in 2009.
Taxonomic status of the subpopulation on Gorgona Island should be reviewed, as it probably corresponds to a different species (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2016)
This species has not been included in phylogenies based on molecular characters, so its evolutionary relationships are still uncertain (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2018).
In spite of its Amazonian type locality, this species is in fact known only from the Andes.
This species and Centrolene scirtetes may be conspecific (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).
This species was considered to be a synonym of Hylopsis platycephalus Werner, 1894, by Lynch (1981b), but this was not accepted by McDiarmid and Savage (1984).
It may be a complex of more than one species (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2010).
The form is the sister species of Pristimantis appendiculatus according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996).
This species was considered a synonym of Hyloxalus fuliginosus by Edwards (1974b).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Allobates brunneus by Silverstone (1971).
This species is considered to be a derivative of Oophaga histrionica by Myers and Daly (1976).

Lötters (1992) doubted the distinction of this species from Oophaga histrionica.

Records from the Serrania de Baudo and Alto del Oso in the Department of Chocó that were previously questioned to belonging to this species have now been verified and assigned as Oophaga solanensis (Posso-Terranova and Andrés 2018).
The validity of this species was previously in question (Lynch pers. comm; Grant and Myers 2013). However, Grant et al. (2017) recognize this taxon as a distinct species.
There is ongoing debate about whether this is a valid species or whether it is a synonym of Hyloxalus pulchellus (T. Grant pers. comm., G. Pisso pers. comm. October 2018).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This form is probably a complex of several species. Brazilian populations assigned to this species presumably belong to another species. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018). It is probably a synonym of Hyloscirtus lindae.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Ruiz-Carranza et al. (1996) noted that one of the paratypes of this species is referable to Hyloscirtus palmeri.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form might represent a species complex.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Atelopus ebenoides (Rueda-Almonacid and Rueda-Martínez 2005)
Bolitoglossa tatamae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Acosta and Hoyos 2006).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).

authority: Amézquita, Márquez, Mejía-Vargas, Kahn, Suárez & Mazariegos, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of A. opisthomelas (Amézquita et al. 2013).

Cryptobatrachus remotus (Infante-Rivero et al. 2009 "2008"), could be a junior synonym of this species based on preliminary evidence (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015, Meza Joya pers. comm. August 2016).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Frost (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis zoilae was based on morphological features and colour patterns (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).

authority: Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This taxon is believed to be the nominal subspecies A. g. guerianus.

It has been confirmed as a valid species through a morphological (shell characters and anatomy of the reproductive system) and genetic (sequencing of a fragment of the mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit 16S rRNA, and the nuclear internal transcriber spacer 1, ITS-1 rRNA) study (Giusti et al. 1995).

Originally placed in genus Imitatrix, this genus was later found to be so close to Lampedusa that no generic dichotomy was needed. It is distinguished from the other species of the genus by virtue of its peculiar buccal pleats and lamellae arrangement. The species has been cited with two more subspecies (L. i. gattoi and L. i. emersoniana) that are now considered as junior synonyms (Giusti et al. 1995).

This species has been sometimes been included in Martes flavigula (e.g., Corbet and Hill 1992), but has been separated as a valid species by other authors (e.g., Pocock 1941, Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951, Anderson 1970, Rozhnov 1995).

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to Pleurodeles nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northern Algeria.

This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Saga campbelli by Kaltenbach (1967) and it was later established as a distinct species based on genetic markers by Kolics et al.(2012). According to M. Lemonnier-Darcemont pers. comm. 2015, there is proof of the synonymy between S. gracilis and S. campbelli.

This species was recently revalidated (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001). It was previously considered to be a synonym of Philautus variabilis. Specimens recorded as P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats of India are now correctly assigned to this species (Bossuyt and Dubious 2001).

This species was recently elevated to species status by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001). Philautus punctatus and P. melanensis (collected by Rao in Karnataka) are considered to be synonyms of this species (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001), but further studies are required to confirm this relationship (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
Several specimens bearing this name, and which are deposited in different museums in India, do not belong to this species (Biju 2001).

Reynolds and Foster (1992) indicated that Atelopus rugulosus is a synonym of A. tricolor. Subsequently, Lötters and De la Riva (1998) confirmed this and pointed out that in evaluating the types of A. rugulosus from south-east Peru, and A. wilimani from Bolivia, both are synonyms of A. tricolor.
Formerly included in the genus Salamandra, this taxon was assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
Many museum specimens assigned to Bufo beddomi are misidentifications (Biju 2001).
Amolops splendissimus and A. caelumnoctis appear to be synonyms for the same species (R. Bain pers. comm. 2009). Until their taxonomic status is resolved, we herein treat both as valid species.
Two distinct subspecies are recognized, C. l. lusitanica and C. l. longipes (Arntzen et al. 2007).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

A number of authors consider Bombina pachypus to be a subspecies of Bombina variegata  based on molecular studies (Bologna et al. 2000, Ohler 1997, Hofman et al. 2007, Fijarczyk et al. 2011). The taxon was elevated to species level by Lanza and Vanni (1991) mainly through the use of preliminary electrophoretic data published in the form of a congress summary (Nascetti et al. 1982) and the studies of Szymura (1998) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) and also on the basis of old morphological evidence (Vaccaneo 1931).

According to recent studies, molecular and morphological characters are not sufficiently suitable to differentiate between N. derjugini and N. microspilotus, contrary to previous assumptions (Schneider and Schneider 2011, Najafimajd et al. 2013, Schneider and Schneider 2013, Hendrix et al. 2014). Therefore, we follow regarding papers, accept N. derjugini as a valid species and N. microspilotus as its junior synonym due to taxonomical priority reasons.
This species has been assigned to the genus Amolops following Stuart (2008); in the Amolops monticola group of Stuart et al. (2010).
Atelopus spumarius barbotini has been suggested to represent a junior synonym of this species (Kok 2000).

Leptopelis grandiceps was resurrected from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis and L. usambarae was transferred from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis to the synonymy L. grandiceps by Gvoždík et al. (2014). It is likely to represent multiple species (S. Loader pers. comm. December 2015).

It has been suggested that this species is a synonym of Phrynobatrachus acridoides, but recent surveys indicate that it differs both in vocalizations and ecology (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.). Phrynobatrachus nigripes, described by Pickersgill (2007), is in fact a synonym of this species (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.).
In the Rhacophorus calcaneus group of Orlov et al. (2012), who noted extensive confusion with Rhacophorus robertingeri in the literature and who discussed previous confusion in the range.
We follow Stuart (2008) in assigning this species to the genus Amolops.

The taxonomy of genus Gazella is complex and several different arrangements have been proposed, but several issues remain unresolved.

Gazella arabica was originally described from a single specimen: a skin and a skull obtained on the Farasan Islands off the coast of Saudi Arabia (or at least labelled as such). This became something of a mystery taxon and is different from the gazelles currently found there. Bärman et al. (2012) extracted DNA from the type specimen and showed that this was not a single specimen, assigning the skin to G. g. cora and the skull to gazelles of the northern type (G. g. gazella).

Wronski et al. (2010) showed that Gazella gazella, in fact, consists of two monophyletic lineages, a northern clade (represented by samples from the Golan Heights) and a southern clade (based on samples from the Arabian Peninsula including the southern Arava Valley), based on mtDNA markers. Lerp et al. (2012) produced similar conclusions using nuclear markers and including samples from Central Israel. A morphological and genetic study of genus Gazella (Bärmann et al. 2013), and a genetic study of gazelles in the southern Levant (Hadas et al. 2015) all further support the existence of two monophyletic lineages: a northern clade (Gazella gazella), and a southern clade (provisionally named G. arabica on the basis that this name takes precedence over cora).

This arrangement is now followed by the IUCN SSC Antelope Specialist Group, with G. gazella replacing G. g. gazella in the former arrangement, and the name G. arabica provisionally retained for the southern clade, pending a ruling by the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN). So G. arabica, as understood here, comprises all the gazelles formerly considered under G. gazella, from the southern Negev through the Arabian Peninsula.

Several subspecies have been named under G. gazella and have previously been evaluated for The IUCN Red List: acaciae; in the southern Arava Valley; cora in most of the Arabian Peninsula; farasani on the Farasan Islands; and muscatensis on the Batinah coast of Oman. Genetic research by scientists at King Khaled Wildlife Research Centre (Saudi Arabia) and Zoological Society of London (ZSL) has confirmed the existence of some intraspecific variation, but there is no agreement on the validity of these named subspecies and they are not assessed separately for the time being, until a definitive analysis has been produced. All of the above are included in G. arabica here.

The relationship between G. arabica (as here) and two other 'mystery' species, G. erlangeri and G. bilkis awaits confirmation.

Often included in Suncus etruscus, we follow Hutterer (2005) in recognizing this as a distinct species. Meegaskumbura et al. (2012a) and Meegaskumbura et al. (2012b) recognise S. fellowesgordoni as sister taxa to S. etruscus and S. malayanus.
Results of the phylogenetic analysis by Weisrock et al. (2006) showed that the Chinese Hainan Island species Tylototriton hainanensis is grouped in a strongly supported clade with T. vietnamensis.

This species is comprised of a well-supported monophyletic group and shows higher levels of genetic divergence among its populations than those of Ameerega hahneli from the same region (Roberts et al. 2007).
This species is very similar to Ameerega petersi. There might be a need to re-examine the relationship between these two taxa.

The status of Ameerega rubriventris as a valid species is still in dispute by some, though the unusual ventral colors and genetic distinctness suggest that this species is indeed different from A. altamazonica (Twomey and Brown 2017).
Prior to the official description in 1979, this species was known to many people but under incorrect names, such as Phyllobates bicolor.
This genus moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

On the basis of larval morphology, Aguilar and Pacheco (2005) suggested that this species should be in Telmatobius, although they did not make the nomenclatural change from Batrachophrynus (Frost 2014).
Two subspecies are recognized: Ceratophrys stolzmanni ssp. scaphiopeza in Ecuador, and C. stolzmanni ssp. stolzmanni in Peru.
Pristimantis vermiculatus is considered to be a junior synonym of Pristimantis petrobardus (Duellman and Lehr 2009).
According to Lehr and Catenazzi (2009), Psychrophrynella bagrecito (Lynch 1986) seems to be related to Noblella rather than to Psychrophrynella (Lehr 2006, De la Riva et al. 2008).
The specimen from Cajamarca, Peru previously attributed to Lynchius parkeri by Lehr (2006) has been assigned to Lynchius oblitus based on phylogenetic analyses (Motta et al. 2016).

Reflecting some taxonomic uncertainty, Pristimantis simonsii has been included in other genera over the recent past. Currently, there is apparent consensus that the species should be in the genus Pristimantis.
Atelopus pyrodactylus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas and Barrio 2006).
The identity and relations of Pristimantis albertus are assessed through DNA analyses (Duellman and Hedges 2007).
This species is assigned to the festae species group (Moravec et al. 2014).
Microkayla boettgeri can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Lehr 2006).

In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis according to AmphibiaWeb (2008). Pristimantis wagteri is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas 2007).

In the Eleutherodactylus (Eleutherodactylus) orestes group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007). Pristimantis cordovae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).
Atelopus epikeisthos can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lötters et al. 2004).
This species was formerly included within Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).
This species was formerly classified as Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
(Köhler, Koscinski, Padial, Chaparro, Handford, Lougheed & De la Riva, 2010)

taxonomicNotes: In the Hypsiboas calcaratus complex and differentiable from H. alfaroi only by genetic markers or call (Caminer and Ron 2014).

Historically, there has been some doubt over the distinctiveness of this taxon from Rhinella spinulosa (Gorham 1974, Córdova 1999). However, it is considered a distinct species from the broader concept of Rhinella spinulosa (Cei 1972, Cei 1980). 

Morphological and molecular studies are needed to clarify the distribution of Rhinella in southern Peru (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018).
Named as Philautus decoris by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda in 2005, the genus has been revised and replaced with Pseudophilautus by Li et al. in 2009.
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 9952. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum) RMNH collection number 5004178

Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14679. Type material deposited in RMNH
 (Netherlands Natural History Museum). RMNH collection number 5004176
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14681. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum) RMNH collection number 5004177

This species possibly represents a distinct genus from Cyclophorus.

Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14693. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum).RMNH collection number 5004182
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14689. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum) RMNH collection number 5004179
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14688. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum). RMNH collection number 5004173

This species possibly represents a distinct genus from Cyclophorus.

Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14684. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum) RMNH collection number 5004181
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14690. Type material will be deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum)
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 9955[MS1] . Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum). RMNH collection number 5004174
Voucher specimen: coll. Vermeulen 14691. Type material deposited in RMNH (Netherlands Natural History Museum) RMNH collection number RMNH 5004175
Named as Philautus hallidayi by Meegaskumbura and Manamendra-Arachchi in 2005, the genus has been revised and replaced with Pseudophilautus by Li et al. in 2009.

The population in Sri Lanka assigned to Hylarana aurantiaca probably belongs to an undescribed species (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.). However, pending taxonomic revision, H. aurantiaca is treated here as a single species.
Pseudoeurycea boneti has recently been resurrected from synonymy with P. bellii (Parra-Olea et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to Isthmura (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2012). It was previously removed from the synonymy of Isthmura bellii by Parra-Olea et al. (2001 - as Pseudoeurycea bellii).

Anonyxmolytes lilliput is the only species of the genus Anonyxmolytes, which is restricted to the Hon Chong limestone hills (Meregalli and Osella 2007), possibly extending into nearby areas in Cambodia (Deharveng pers. comm). It is well characterized within the subfamily Molytinae, and unique among Curculionidae by the extreme reduction of its tarsi. It is a blind species of low vagility, associated with deep soil, and highly specialized, probably very sensitive to change in the habitat conditions (deforestation, changes in the water-content of the soil, etc.). It is possibly related to a Japanese genus, and appears to be a relict taxon of high phylogenetic and biogeographic interest (Meregalli, Pers. Comm.).
Eustra honchongensis belongs to a genus including species which are all rare and narrowly endemic in Southeast Asia (Deuve, 1996).

Eutrichodesmus griseus belongs to a genus that includes a large number of species in Southeast Asia, mostly in caves and all narrow endemics. It is unusual morphologically compared to its congeners, because of its greyish coloration. E. griseus is the only species of the genus in the Hon Chong region (Golovatch et al., 2009).
Groves (2002) provisionally listed two subspecies of Grevy's Zebra. However, Groves and Bell (2004) concluded that the species is indeed monotypic. Reviewed by Churcher (1993).

Gnomulus bedoharvengorum is a species of the large Indo-Malayan genus Gnomulus. The Hon Chong species is biologically of interest because of its occurrence in caves and rarer occurrence in surface litter under bushes, while most other species of the genus live in rainforest litter. It appears as a relictual form in this respect.

Isometrus deharvengi belongs to the rather large genus Isometrus, which is known from Vietnam and surrounding countries by several species (Lourenço & Duhem, 2010). All species of the genus except one have reduced distribution areas. The presence of I. deharvengi in caves is unusual for the genus Isometrus, though the species is not troglomorphic.

Microblattellus lecongmani is a remarkable species, the only species of the genus Microblattellus. The new tribe Falsocossyphini was erected to accomodate it together with two other monospecific genera (Ferrer 2006). The unusual morphology of those species casts doubts on the monophyly of this tribe, but not on the originality of the species it includes (Bremer & Lillig 2014). It has therefore to be considered as one of the most remarkable endemic species of Hon Chong, and a major issue regarding biodiversity conservation, though the species is less strongly threatened than many others from the Hon Chong-Kampot karst.

scientificName: Burmoniscus sp. nov. 'HC - first segment white'
taxonomicNotes: Species under description by Stefano Taiti and Giovanna Monticelli Cardoso (May 2016), vouchers in Firenze (1 specimen), and 2 specimens to be deposited in MNHN Paris (Taiti 2016, pers. comm.).

Species under description by Louis Deharveng and Anne Bedos, vouchers in MNHN Paris (6 specimens), to be deposited in Ho Chi Minh City University and MNHN Paris.

Ceratophysella sp. nov. 'HC' is a new undescribed species of Hypogastruridae Collembola, assumed to be related to temperate region species of the genus. Its is a remarkable relict restricted to one cave of the Hon Chong hills, and the only non-guanobitic cave Hypogastruridae known from the tropics.

Until 2003, all Scleropages from Southeast Asia were considered to belong to the same species; S. formosus. In 2003 Pouyaud et al., considered there to actually be four species, three of which they described as new (S. aureus, S. legendrei, S. macrocephalus). Kottelat and Widjanarti (2005) reviewed the published data and did not reach the same conclusions from the quality of the data presented, and in order for more than one species to be recognised, a professional standard study would need to be presented. In 2012, a new species (S. incriptus) was described from Myanmar (Roberts 2012).

The former Anniella pulchra was divided into five species by Papenfuss and Parham (2013). Parham and Papenfuss (2009) speculated that the Carrizo Plain subpopulation may be a hybrid or intergrade subpopulation, but Papenfuss and Parham (2013) included it in their concept of A. grinnelli.

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been regarded as a subpopulation of Ecnomiohyla rabborum, but is now regarded as a distinct species as a result of morphology and molecular examination of specimens (Batista et al. 2014).

Populations of a Paedocypris species in Peninsular Malaysia have been provisionally identified as this species. However, there is ongoing genetic analysis to determine whether they represent Paedocypris micromegethes (H.H. Tan pers. comm. 2019).

Mokodongan et al. (2018) found that the Oryzias woworae species group (comprising of O. asinua, O. wolasi, and O. woworae) could not be separated by their body shape using geometric morphometrics and that their phylogenetic relationships did not support the presence of three species. As such, they recommend a taxonomic re-examination of the O.woworae species group.
Chlamydotis undulata and C. macqueenii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. undulata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. Chelonoidis donfaustoi is a recently described species (Poulakakis et al. 2015), previously included within C. porteri. The name C. porteri is now restricted only to the species of tortoise found on western Santa Cruz Island in the area known as La Reserva (the originally designated Tortoise Reserve). This Red List assessment treats this newly described taxon, C. donfaustoi, as a full species.

Microtus bavaricus is part of Microtus multiplex species-complex. Its formerly continuous range in the Alps was split into three parts during the last glaciation which led to the evolution of three species: Microtus liechtensteini (south of the Alps east of the river Adige and Balkan mountains), Microtus multiplex (south of the Alps west of the river Adige), and M. bavaricus (north of the Alps in a small refuge in Bavaria and Northern Tyrol) (Haring et al. 2000, Spitzenberger et al. 2000, Spitzenberger 2002, Musser and Carleton 2005, Martinkova et al. 2007).
This species may be a species complex, and further taxonomic work is required to verify this (K.O. Chan and E. Quah pers. comm. January 2018).
